Digestive (Lactose Intolerance).CategoryDescription: This category covers treatments aimed at managing symptoms associated with lactose intolerance and related digestive disturbances. Effective management supports proper digestion and nutrient absorption.

Lactase Enzyme.Description: An enzyme supplement that breaks down lactose, reducing symptoms of lactose intolerance.
Lactase Enzyme.Dosage: 1 tablet before or with dairy consumption
Lactase Enzyme.Notes: Clinically proven to enhance lactose digestion.

Anti-Diarrheal.Description: A medication that slows intestinal motility to help control diarrhea.
Anti-Diarrheal.Dosage: 2 mg initially; 1 mg for each subsequent loose stool

Ginger Tea.Description: A herbal tea that soothes nausea and supports overall digestive comfort.
Ginger Tea.Notes: Widely used for its natural digestive relief properties.
Ginger Tea.Preparation: Steep 1-2 teaspoons of grated ginger in boiling water for 10 minutes

Flu/Fever.CategoryDescription:
Treatments for flu and fever.

These remedies reduce high temperatures and alleviate body aches.

If left untreated, flu may lead to further complications such as dehydration or secondary infections.

Acetaminophen.Description: Reduces fever and alleviates body aches reliably.
Acetaminophen.Notes: Clinically proven for flu and fever relief.

Elderberry Syrup.Description: May shorten the duration of flu and reduce symptom severity.
Elderberry Syrup.Notes: Supported by clinical studies for flu relief.

Toothache.CategoryDescription: Toothache is dental pain that may result from cavities, pulpitis, periodontal infections, or dental abscesses. Effective management is crucial to alleviate pain, prevent the progression of infection, and avoid further damage to oral tissues.

Ibuprofen.Description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces pain and inflammation, making it a common first-line treatment for toothache relief.
Ibuprofen.Maximum: Do not exceed 1200 mg per day for OTC use (follow specific prescription guidelines if applicable)
Ibuprofen.Notes: Take with food to minimize gastrointestinal irritation. If pain persists beyond a few days, a dental evaluation is recommended to address the underlying cause.
Ibuprofen.Alternatives: Acetaminophen may be used as an alternative, especially for those who cannot tolerate NSAIDs.
Ibuprofen.AgeGroup: Adults and children (with appropriate pediatric dosing adjustments)

Clove Oil.Description: Clove oil is an herbal remedy known for its analgesic and antiseptic properties, largely due to its active ingredient, eugenol. It provides temporary relief from toothache when applied topically.
Clove Oil.Dosage: Apply 1-2 drops to a cotton ball
Clove Oil.Frequency: Up to 3-4 times daily as needed
Clove Oil.Maximum: Use only as directed to avoid irritation
Clove Oil.Notes: Always dilute clove oil with a carrier oil (such as olive or coconut oil) before applying to the affected area to prevent mucosal irritation. While effective for temporary relief, clove oil does not treat the underlying dental issue; a professional dental consultation is advised if pain persists.
Clove Oil.Alternatives: Garlic extract may provide similar antimicrobial and analgesic benefits but is less commonly used for toothache relief.
Clove Oil.AgeGroup: Adults; use with caution in children

Burns.CategoryDescription:
Treatments for minor burns.

These remedies help soothe burn pain, prevent infection, and promote healing.

Timely treatment is important to avoid complications such as scarring or infection.

Silver Sulfadiazine Cream.Description: Prevents and treats burn infections effectively.
Silver Sulfadiazine Cream.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the burn area
Silver Sulfadiazine Cream.Notes: Standard burn treatment in clinical practice.

Aloe Vera Gel.Description: Soothes burns and reduces inflammation reliably.
Aloe Vera Gel.Notes: Widely recognized for its burn healing properties.

Cold and Runny Nose.CategoryDescription:
Treatments for nasal congestion and common cold symptoms.

These remedies help clear blocked nasal passages and ease breathing.

Without treatment, prolonged congestion may lead to sinus pressure or secondary infections.

Honey and Lemon Tea.Description: Soothes nasal passages and relieves cold symptoms naturally.
Honey and Lemon Tea.Notes: A natural remedy that combines the antibacterial properties of honey with the soothing effects of lemon.
Honey and Lemon Tea.Preparation: Mix 1 tbsp honey with the juice of 1/2 lemon in warm water

Severe Cough.CategoryDescription:
Treatments to suppress severe coughing episodes.

Severe cough can lead to throat irritation and interfere with sleep.

Effective relief can improve comfort and prevent further complications.

Dextromethorphan Syrup.Description: Suppresses the cough reflex to relieve severe cough.

Dextromethorphan Tablet.Description: A tablet formulation of dextromethorphan that suppresses the cough reflex effectively.
Dextromethorphan Tablet.Notes: Provides a convenient alternative in tablet form for cough suppression.
Dextromethorphan Tablet.Alternatives: Dextromethorphan Syrup, Codeine-based cough suppressants (if prescribed)

Thyme Tea.Notes: Supported by evidence for cough relief.
Thyme Tea.Preparation: Steep 1-2 tsp dried thyme in boiling water for 10 minutes, then strain

Treatments for skin irritation, inflammation, and minor rashes.

Hydrocortisone Cream.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the affected area

Urinary Retention.CategoryDescription:
Treatments for difficulty in urination and urinary retention issues.

These therapies help restore normal bladder function and prevent complications such as urinary tract infections or kidney damage.

Tamsulosin.Description: Relaxes prostate and bladder neck muscles to facilitate urination.

Bethanechol.Description: Stimulates bladder contractions; effective for nonâ€‘obstructive urinary retention in women.
Bethanechol.Notes: Effective for urinary retention in women; use under medical supervision.

Saw Palmetto Extract.Description: May improve urinary symptoms in men with BPH.
Saw Palmetto Extract.Notes: Used as an effective adjunct remedy in men.

Bacterial Infections.CategoryDescription:
Antibiotic and supportive treatments for common bacterial infections.

Bacterial infections are caused by pathogenic bacteria that invade and multiply in body tissues. 

They are often due to contaminated food, water, wounds, or poor hygiene. 

If left untreated, these infections can lead to serious complications such as abscess formation, septicemia, organ damage, and even life-threatening sepsis. 

Timely administration of appropriate antibiotics, along with supportive measures, is essential to bolster the immune response and prevent complications.

Amoxicillin.Description: Broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against common bacterial infections.

Garlic Extract.Description: Exhibits antibacterial properties and may support the immune system as an adjunct to conventional therapy.

Gout.CategoryDescription:
Treatments for gout, an inflammatory form of arthritis caused by elevated uric acid levels.

If not managed, gout can lead to joint damage, chronic pain, and reduced mobility.

Colchicine.Description: Reduces inflammation during acute gout attacks.
Colchicine.Dosage: Approximately 0.6 mg per dose (with possible initial 1.2 mg)
Colchicine.Frequency: As directed during an acute attack

Tart Cherry Juice.Description: May help reduce gout flare frequency and inflammation by lowering uric acid levels.
Tart Cherry Juice.Notes: Evidence supports reduced uric acid levels with regular consumption.

Ginger and Peppermint Tea.Description: A herbal remedy that may help soothe the digestive tract and balance bowel movements, easing both diarrhea and constipation.
Ginger and Peppermint Tea.Notes: Supports overall digestive comfort and regularity.

Abdominal Pain.CategoryDescription: A general symptom that can arise from various causes including infections, inflammatory conditions, or digestive disturbances.

Acetaminophen for Abdominal Pain.Description: Provides pain relief for mild to moderate abdominal pain.
Acetaminophen for Abdominal Pain.Notes: Helps reduce pain without causing additional stomach upset.

Hyoscine Butylbromide.Description: An antispasmodic that relieves cramping abdominal pain by relaxing smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract.
Hyoscine Butylbromide.Notes: Effective for spasmodic abdominal pain; consult a healthcare provider if pain persists.

Peppermint Tea.Description: Peppermint tea may help soothe the digestive tract and relieve mild abdominal discomfort through its antispasmodic properties.
Peppermint Tea.Notes: Helps relax gastrointestinal muscles and ease cramping.

Chest Pain and Tightness.CategoryDescription: May indicate respiratory issues (such as pneumonia or bronchitis), cardiac problems, or even gastrointestinal reflux in some cases.

Nitroglycerin.Description: A vasodilator that helps relieve chest pain associated with cardiac conditions such as angina by dilating blood vessels and reducing cardiac workload.
Nitroglycerin.Frequency: At onset of chest pain; may repeat every 5 minutes for up to 3 doses
Nitroglycerin.Notes: Used for cardiac-related chest pain; if pain persists, seek emergency care immediately.

Omeprazole.Description: A proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid, alleviating chest pain associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Omeprazole.Frequency: Once daily, preferably before a meal
Omeprazole.Notes: Helps reduce acid reflux symptoms that can contribute to chest tightness.

Hawthorn Berry Extract.Description: Traditionally used to support cardiovascular health, hawthorn berry extract may help improve blood flow and reduce mild chest discomfort in non-emergency situations.
Hawthorn Berry Extract.Notes: Not a substitute for emergency treatment in cases of severe chest pain; used as a supportive remedy.

Shortness of Breath (Dyspnea).CategoryDescription: Frequently noted in respiratory infections, asthma, and cardiac conditions. It can also be related to anxiety in some instances.

Albuterol Inhaler.Description: A bronchodilator that relaxes airway muscles to improve airflow, providing rapid relief from shortness of breath.
Albuterol Inhaler.Notes: Effective for rapid relief of asthma and other respiratory conditions causing dyspnea.

Mullein Tea.Description: Traditionally used to soothe the respiratory tract, mullein tea may help alleviate mild shortness of breath naturally.
Mullein Tea.Notes: Provides a natural option to support respiratory comfort.

Dizziness, Lightheadedness, or Fainting.CategoryDescription: These can occur with infections, dehydration, low blood pressure, or as side effects of medications.

Meclizine.Description: An antihistamine that helps reduce symptoms of dizziness and vertigo.
Meclizine.Notes: Helps reduce the sensation of dizziness and vertigo; may cause drowsiness.

Ginger.Description: Ginger may help alleviate dizziness and associated nausea by promoting circulation and reducing nausea naturally.
Ginger.Notes: Useful for mild dizziness and nausea.

Palpitations.CategoryDescription: An awareness of a rapid, strong, or irregular heartbeat, which can be associated with fever, anxiety, or certain infections.

Beta-blockers.Description: Beta-blockers help reduce heart rate and control palpitations by blocking the effects of adrenaline.
Beta-blockers.Frequency: Once or twice daily as prescribed
Beta-blockers.Notes: Patients should consult a healthcare provider before use, especially if they have asthma or other respiratory conditions.

Hawthorn Berry Extract.Description: Traditionally used to support cardiovascular health, hawthorn berry extract may help improve blood flow and reduce mild palpitations.
Hawthorn Berry Extract.Notes: Serves as a supportive remedy and is not a substitute for professional medical advice.

Itching (Pruritus) and Rashes.CategoryDescription: Skin irritation characterized by itching and various rashes, which may indicate allergic reactions or systemic conditions.

Diphenhydramine.Description: An antihistamine that alleviates itching and allergic reactions by blocking histamine receptors.
Diphenhydramine.Notes: May cause drowsiness; avoid activities that require full alertness.

Aloe Vera Gel.Description: Topically applied aloe vera gel soothes irritated skin and reduces inflammation associated with rashes.
Aloe Vera Gel.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the affected area
Aloe Vera Gel.Notes: Provides a cooling effect and helps calm inflammation.

Edema (Swelling).CategoryDescription: Edema is the accumulation of fluid in body tissues, often seen as swelling in the extremities, and may indicate underlying cardiovascular, renal, or inflammatory issues.

Furosemide.Description: A loop diuretic that promotes the excretion of sodium and water, thereby reducing fluid retention. It is commonly used to manage edema associated with heart failure or kidney disorders.
Furosemide.Frequency: Once or twice daily as prescribed
Furosemide.Notes: Monitor electrolyte levels and kidney function; adjust dosage based on patient response.

Dandelion Root Tea.Description: A natural diuretic that may help reduce fluid retention by increasing urine production and supporting kidney function. Traditionally used for mild cases of edema.
Dandelion Root Tea.Notes: Consult a healthcare provider if swelling persists.

Loss of Appetite and Unintended Weight C.CategoryDescription: A decreased desire to eat, resulting in weight loss or sometimes weight gain, which may be associated with systemic infections, chronic illnesses, or metabolic disorders.

Megestrol Acetate.Description: An appetite stimulant that helps promote weight gain and improve appetite in patients experiencing unintended weight loss due to chronic conditions.
Megestrol Acetate.Notes: Should be used under medical supervision due to potential side effects including thromboembolic events and adrenal suppression.

Gentian Root Extract.Description: A bitter herbal remedy traditionally used to naturally stimulate appetite and improve digestion.
Gentian Root Extract.Notes: May help promote appetite in mild cases; always adhere to manufacturer instructions.

Neurological Symptoms (Numbness, Tinglin.CategoryDescription: These symptoms can sometimes be seen with infections that affect the nervous system, electrolyte imbalances, or other systemic conditions.

Gabapentin.Description: An anticonvulsant used off-label to manage neuropathic pain and abnormal sensations such as numbness and tingling.
Gabapentin.Maximum: Depends on patient tolerance and condition
Gabapentin.Notes: Dosage should be individualized; monitor for side effects such as drowsiness or dizziness.

B Vitamin Complex.Description: A B vitamin complex, particularly vitamins B1, B6, and B12, supports nerve health and may help alleviate symptoms of numbness and tingling.
B Vitamin Complex.Notes: Supports overall nerve function; consult a healthcare provider for proper dosage.

Mood Changes or Irritability.CategoryDescription: Some illnesses can affect mood, leading to increased irritability, anxiety, or even confusion, particularly when accompanied by fatigue or pain.

Lorazepam.Description: A benzodiazepine that helps reduce anxiety and may alleviate mood changes associated with stress or illness.
Lorazepam.Notes: Short-term use is recommended due to potential dependency and side effects.

Passionflower.Description: A herbal remedy traditionally used to help ease anxiety and promote relaxation, potentially improving mood and reducing irritability.
Passionflower.Dosage: 250-500 mg per dose (capsule) or 1 cup per serving (tea)
Passionflower.Notes: May help reduce mild anxiety and irritability naturally.
Passionflower.QuantityNeeded: 250-500 mg per dose (capsule) or 1 cup per serving (tea)

Generalized Weakness or Malaise.CategoryDescription: A feeling of being unwell or overall weakness is common in many acute and chronic illnesses, even when specific organ systems are not directly affected.

Modafinil.Description: A wakefulness-promoting agent that may help alleviate fatigue and improve alertness in patients experiencing generalized weakness or malaise. It is typically considered for chronic fatigue or specific neurological conditions.
Modafinil.Notes: Use under strict medical supervision; not suitable for all patients.

Ginseng (Panax Ginseng).Description: An adaptogenic herb traditionally used to enhance energy levels, improve stamina, and reduce feelings of fatigue and malaise.
Ginseng (Panax Ginseng).Notes: May help improve overall energy and reduce weakness; consult a healthcare provider if symptoms persist.

Back Pain.CategoryDescription: Back pain is a common symptom often resulting from muscle strain, herniated discs, or osteoarthritis. Proper management may involve pain relievers, physical therapy, and supportive care.

Ibuprofen.Description: A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that helps reduce inflammation and relieve pain associated with back pain.
Ibuprofen.Notes: Take with food to minimize gastrointestinal discomfort.

Arnica Gel.Description: A topical remedy traditionally used to alleviate pain and reduce inflammation in cases of muscle strain or injury.
Arnica Gel.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the affected area
Arnica Gel.Notes: For external use only; avoid applying on broken skin.

Joint Pain (Arthralgia).CategoryDescription: Joint pain (arthralgia) can be caused by arthritis, injuries, or inflammatory conditions. It often presents as pain, stiffness, and sometimes swelling in one or more joints.

Ibuprofen.Description: A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that helps reduce inflammation and relieve pain associated with joint pain.
Ibuprofen.Notes: Take with food to minimize gastrointestinal discomfort.

Turmeric Extract.Description: Contains curcumin, a natural anti-inflammatory compound that may help reduce joint inflammation and alleviate pain.
Turmeric Extract.Notes: Often combined with black pepper extract to enhance absorption; effects may take several weeks to be noticeable.

Difficulty Swallowing (Dysphagia).CategoryDescription: Difficulty swallowing, or dysphagia, can result from various causes including esophageal motility disorders, neurological conditions, or structural abnormalities. It is characterized by a sensation of food or liquid sticking in the throat and may require diagnostic evaluation and tailored treatment.
Symptoms: Sensation of food sticking in the throat

Metoclopramide.Description: A prokinetic agent that can help improve esophageal motility and reduce symptoms of dysphagia, especially when associated with reflux or gastroparesis.
Metoclopramide.Frequency: 30 minutes before meals and at bedtime
Metoclopramide.Notes: Use with caution due to potential side effects such as drowsiness and extrapyramidal symptoms; not intended for long-term use.

Licorice Root Extract.Description: Licorice root extract may help soothe the esophageal lining and reduce inflammation, potentially easing mild dysphagia symptoms related to reflux.
Licorice Root Extract.Notes: Use with caution in individuals with hypertension or kidney issues.

Swollen Lymph Nodes (Lymphadenopathy).CategoryDescription: Swollen lymph nodes, or lymphadenopathy, are commonly a sign of an immune response to infection, inflammation, or other underlying conditions. They may present as tender or non-tender lumps in various regions and, if persistent or accompanied by systemic symptoms, warrant further medical evaluation.

Ibuprofen.Description: An NSAID that helps reduce inflammation and alleviate pain associated with swollen lymph nodes, particularly when the swelling is due to inflammatory causes.
Ibuprofen.Notes: Use with caution in patients with gastrointestinal, kidney, or cardiovascular issues. Not recommended for long-term use without medical supervision.
Ibuprofen.Alternatives: Acetaminophen (for pain relief without significant anti-inflammatory effects)

Echinacea.Description: Echinacea is believed to support the immune system and may help the body combat infections that can lead to lymph node swelling.
Echinacea.Notes: Consult with a healthcare provider before use, especially for individuals with autoimmune conditions or those on immunosuppressive therapy.

Eye Irritations or Conjunctivitis.CategoryDescription: Eye irritations or conjunctivitis typically involve redness, itching, or watering of the eyes. These symptoms can be triggered by allergies, infections, or environmental factors, and may require appropriate treatment to alleviate discomfort and prevent further complications.

Olopatadine.Description: Olopatadine is an antihistamine and mast cell stabilizer used to relieve the symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis, including redness, itching, and watering of the eyes.
Olopatadine.Dosage: One drop in each affected eye
Olopatadine.Notes: Avoid contamination by not touching the dropper tip to any surface. Consult an ophthalmologist if symptoms persist or worsen.
Olopatadine.AgeGroup: Adults and children (if approved for pediatric use)

Eyebright.Description: Eyebright is a traditional herbal remedy believed to help soothe eye irritations and reduce inflammation, potentially alleviating redness, itching, and watering of the eyes.
Eyebright.Notes: Ensure the preparation is sterile if used as an eye wash. Consult a healthcare provider if symptoms persist, especially if signs of infection develop.

Urinary Symptoms.CategoryDescription: Urinary symptoms, such as dysuria (painful or difficult urination) or frequent urination often seen in UTIs, can cause discomfort and may indicate an underlying urinary tract infection. Prompt evaluation and appropriate treatment are essential to prevent complications.

Nitrofurantoin.Description: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic frequently prescribed for uncomplicated urinary tract infections. It works by inhibiting bacterial processes necessary for survival, thereby reducing the infection and alleviating symptoms such as dysuria and frequent urination.
Nitrofurantoin.Notes: Ensure completion of the full prescribed course. Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.

Cranberry Extract.Description: Cranberry extract is traditionally used to help prevent bacteria from adhering to the urinary tract lining, potentially reducing the risk of UTIs and alleviating mild urinary symptoms such as dysuria and frequent urination.
Cranberry Extract.Notes: While cranberry extract may help in prevention, it should not replace antibiotic treatment in active infections.

Tetanus.CategoryDescription: Tetanus is a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, characterized by muscle stiffness, spasms, and lockjaw. The bacteria typically enter the body through contaminated wounds, making prompt treatment critical to prevent severe complications.

Tetanus Immunoglobulin.Description: Tetanus Immunoglobulin is used as an immediate post-exposure treatment to neutralize the tetanus toxin in cases of tetanus, a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani. It provides passive immunity and is essential for patients who are unvaccinated or have an uncertain vaccination history.
Tetanus Immunoglobulin.Frequency: Single dose, with additional doses based on clinical evaluation if necessary
Tetanus Immunoglobulin.Notes: Administer as soon as possible after a suspected exposure. Follow up with active immunization for long-term protection.

Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine.Description: The Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine is used for active immunization against tetanus, a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani. It stimulates the body to produce antibodies against the tetanus toxin and is a critical component of both routine immunization schedules and post-exposure prophylaxis.
Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine.Frequency: Initial dose followed by booster shots every 10 years
Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine.Notes: Complete the full vaccination series for long-term protection. Combined vaccines (e.g., DTaP) may be used as alternatives.

Echinacea.Description: Echinacea is sometimes used to support overall immune function, which may be beneficial as a complementary approach during recovery from tetanus, a serious bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani. However, it should not replace conventional tetanus treatments or prophylaxis.
Echinacea.Notes: Should only be used as a complementary treatment. It must not replace conventional tetanus treatments or prophylaxis.

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs).CategoryDescription: Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs) are common, particularly in women, and are frequently encountered in primary care. They typically involve an infection of the urinary tract, most often caused by bacteria such as Escherichia coli.

Nitrofurantoin.Description: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat UTIs. It works by inhibiting bacterial cell processes essential for survival, thereby reducing the infection and alleviating symptoms.
Nitrofurantoin.Notes: Ensure the full course is completed even if symptoms improve. Use with caution in patients with renal impairment.

Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole.Description: Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole is a commonly prescribed antibiotic combination used to treat UTIs. It works by inhibiting bacterial folate synthesis, thereby effectively treating the infection.
Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole.Notes: Adjust dosage based on kidney function and patient tolerance. Contraindicated in patients with sulfa allergies.

Cranberry Extract.Description: Cranberry Extract is used as a complementary approach to help prevent UTIs by inhibiting the adherence of bacteria to the urinary tract lining. It may be taken alongside conventional treatments to reduce recurrence.
Cranberry Extract.Notes: Not a substitute for antibiotics during an active infection but may help reduce recurrence.

Sinusitis.CategoryDescription: Sinusitis, an inflammation of the sinuses, often with nasal congestion and facial pain, can result from infections, allergies, or environmental factors, and appropriate treatment is necessary to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.

Amoxicillin-Clavulanate.Description: Amoxicillin-Clavulanate is an antibiotic commonly prescribed for sinusitis (inflammation of the sinuses, often with nasal congestion and facial pain). It works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, thereby reducing the infection and alleviating associated symptoms.
Amoxicillin-Clavulanate.Notes: Complete the full prescribed course even if symptoms improve. Use with caution in patients with a penicillin allergy.

Eucalyptus.Description: Eucalyptus oil, used in steam inhalation, may help alleviate sinusitis symptoms by loosening mucus and reducing nasal congestion and facial pain associated with inflammation of the sinuses.
Eucalyptus.Notes: Do not ingest; use only for inhalation or topical application after proper dilution. Not recommended for young children.

Ear Infections (Otitis Media).CategoryDescription: Ear infections, known as Otitis Media, are infections of the middle ear that are particularly common in children. These infections can cause ear pain, fever, and temporary hearing difficulties, and may require prompt treatment to avoid complications.

Amoxicillin.Description: Amoxicillin is a commonly prescribed antibiotic for Ear Infections (Otitis Media), particularly common in children. It targets the bacteria responsible for the infection, reducing inflammation and alleviating pain.
Amoxicillin.Dosage: Based on weight and severity, typically 20-40 mg/kg/day
Amoxicillin.Notes: Dosage should be determined by a pediatrician based on the child's weight and condition. Complete the full course of therapy.

Garlic Extract.Description: Garlic extract, known for its natural antimicrobial properties, is sometimes used as a complementary remedy for Ear Infections (Otitis Media), particularly common in children. It may help reduce bacterial growth and inflammation.
Garlic Extract.Notes: Not a substitute for conventional treatment. Consult a healthcare provider before use, especially for children.

Migraines.CategoryDescription: Migraines, severe, recurrent headaches often accompanied by nausea or sensitivity to light, can significantly impact daily activities and quality of life. Effective management often requires both acute and preventive treatments.

Sumatriptan.Description: Sumatriptan is a selective serotonin receptor agonist used to treat migraines (severe, recurrent headaches often accompanied by nausea or sensitivity to light). It works by narrowing blood vessels and reducing inflammation in the brain, thereby alleviating migraine symptoms.
Sumatriptan.Frequency: At onset of migraine; may repeat after 2 hours if necessary
Sumatriptan.Notes: Not recommended for patients with cardiovascular disease. Consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and management.

Feverfew.Description: Feverfew is an herbal remedy traditionally used as a complementary approach to help prevent migraines (severe, recurrent headaches often accompanied by nausea or sensitivity to light). It may help reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.
Feverfew.Notes: Consult a healthcare provider before use, especially if taking other medications or if pregnant.

Anxiety Disorders/Depression.CategoryDescription: Anxiety Disorders and Depression are mood disorders that may be either primary or secondary to chronic illness, characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, worry, or anxiety that interfere with daily functioning.

Sertraline.Description: Sertraline is an SSRI used to treat anxiety disorders and depression. It works by increasing serotonin levels in the brain, helping to improve mood and reduce anxiety.
Sertraline.Notes: It may take several weeks to achieve full therapeutic effect. Monitor for side effects such as nausea, insomnia, and sexual dysfunction.

St. John's Wort.Description: St. John's Wort is an herbal remedy traditionally used for mild to moderate depression and anxiety. It is believed to work by modulating neurotransmitter activity.
St. John's Wort.Notes: Consult with a healthcare provider before use, especially if taking other medications, due to potential drug interactions.

Hypertension (High Blood Pressure).CategoryDescription: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure) is a common cardiovascular condition characterized by persistently elevated blood pressure, which can increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and other complications.

Lisinopril.Description: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to manage hypertension (High Blood Pressure), a common cardiovascular condition. It works by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and a reduction in blood pressure.
Lisinopril.Notes: Monitor kidney function and potassium levels; dosage adjustments may be necessary based on patient response.
Lisinopril.Alternatives: Other ACE inhibitors or ARBs (e.g., Losartan)

Garlic Extract.Description: Garlic Extract is an herbal remedy believed to support cardiovascular health by helping to lower blood pressure in patients with hypertension (High Blood Pressure), a common cardiovascular condition. It is used as a complementary approach alongside conventional treatments.
Garlic Extract.Notes: Should not replace prescribed antihypertensive medications. Consult a healthcare provider before use, especially if taking blood-thinning medications.

Hypertension (High Blood Pressure).CategoryDescription: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure) is a chronic cardiovascular condition defined by persistently elevated arterial blood pressure. Over time, it increases the risk of heart disease, stroke, kidney damage, and other serious complications.

Lisinopril.Description: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor that helps lower blood pressure by blocking the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. This inhibition promotes vasodilation, reducing cardiac workload and blood pressure.
Lisinopril.Dosage: 10 mg per day (subject to adjustment based on clinical response)
Lisinopril.Notes: Regular monitoring of kidney function and serum potassium levels is advised. Dosage adjustments may be necessary depending on patient-specific factors.
Lisinopril.Alternatives: Other ACE inhibitors or ARBs (e.g., Losartan)

Garlic Extract.Description: Garlic Extract is used as a complementary approach to support cardiovascular health. It may modestly lower blood pressure through its antioxidant and vasodilatory properties.
Garlic Extract.Notes: Not intended to replace prescribed antihypertensive medications. Consult a healthcare provider before use, especially if taking blood-thinning medications.

Diabetes Mellitus.CategoryDescription: Diabetes Mellitus, particularly Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by elevated blood sugar levels due to insulin resistance and/or insulin deficiency. Long-term management through lifestyle modifications and medications is essential to prevent complications.

Metformin.Description: Metformin is the first-line oral medication for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. It reduces hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity, thereby lowering blood glucose levels.
Metformin.Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day (adjusted according to patient response)
Metformin.Notes: Monitor kidney function and gastrointestinal tolerance; dosage adjustments may be necessary.
Metformin.Alternatives: Other oral hypoglycemic agents (e.g., Sulfonylureas, DPP-4 inhibitors)

Cinnamon Extract.Description: Cinnamon Extract is used as a complementary treatment in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. It may help improve insulin sensitivity and support blood sugar regulation through its bioactive compounds.
Cinnamon Extract.Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to, not a substitute for, conventional therapies. Consult a healthcare provider before use.

Asthma / Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary D.CategoryDescription: Asthma and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) are common respiratory conditions that require both acute and chronic treatment approaches. Asthma is characterized by reversible airway obstruction and inflammation, while COPD is associated with persistent airflow limitation and progressive lung damage.

Albuterol Inhaler.Description: Albuterol is a short-acting beta2-agonist used for quick relief of bronchospasm in patients with asthma and COPD. It works by relaxing the smooth muscles in the airways, providing prompt relief from symptoms such as wheezing and shortness of breath.
Albuterol Inhaler.Dosage: 90-100 mcg per puff (2 puffs as needed)
Albuterol Inhaler.Notes: Monitor for side effects such as tachycardia; use as a rescue medication only.

Mullein Tea.Description: Mullein Tea is a traditional herbal remedy used to soothe the respiratory tract in patients with asthma and COPD. It is believed to help reduce inflammation and support lung health.
Mullein Tea.Notes: Consult with a healthcare provider before use, especially for severe respiratory conditions.

Arthritis / Joint Pain.CategoryDescription: Arthritis / Joint Pain includes conditions such as osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by chronic joint pain, stiffness, and inflammation. Management often combines conventional medications with complementary herbal treatments to alleviate pain and improve joint function.
Symptoms: Morning stiffness or stiffness after inactivity

Ibuprofen.Description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation associated with arthritis and joint pain.
Ibuprofen.Maximum: 1200-2400 mg per day, as per treatment guidelines
Ibuprofen.Notes: Take with food to minimize gastrointestinal discomfort; monitor for side effects such as stomach upset or kidney issues.

Turmeric Extract.Description: Turmeric Extract, rich in curcumin, is used as a complementary treatment for arthritis. It may help reduce inflammation and alleviate joint pain when used as part of a comprehensive management plan.
Turmeric Extract.Notes: May improve joint mobility and reduce pain; best used in conjunction with conventional therapies.

Lower Back Pain.CategoryDescription: Lower Back Pain is one of the most frequent complaints, often managed with over-the-counter remedies and physical therapy. It can result from muscle strain, degenerative disc disease, or other musculoskeletal issues.
Symptoms: Dull, persistent ache in the lower back
Stiffness and reduced range of motion

Acetaminophen.Description: Acetaminophen is an over-the-counter pain reliever commonly used to manage lower back pain by alleviating pain and reducing fever, although it lacks the anti-inflammatory effects of NSAIDs.
Acetaminophen.Notes: Do not exceed the maximum daily dosage to avoid liver damage. Consult a healthcare provider if pain persists.
Acetaminophen.Alternatives: NSAIDs such as Ibuprofen or Naproxen

Devil's Claw.Description: Devil's Claw is an herbal remedy traditionally used to help alleviate lower back pain and reduce inflammation. It may assist in improving mobility and decreasing discomfort.
Devil's Claw.Notes: Consult with a healthcare provider before use, especially if taking other medications or if you have underlying health conditions.

Mental Health Conditions (Anxiety and De.CategoryDescription: Mental Health Conditions (Anxiety and Depression) are very common and, although not always 'symptomatic' in the traditional sense, are managed with medications and therapies. They often require a comprehensive treatment plan that may include both conventional and complementary approaches.
Symptoms: Loss of interest or pleasure in activities

Sertraline.Description: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used to manage anxiety and depression by increasing serotonin levels in the brain, which helps improve mood and reduce anxiety.
Sertraline.Dosage: 50 mg per day (may be adjusted based on patient response)
Sertraline.Notes: Monitor for side effects such as nausea, insomnia, and sexual dysfunction; dosage adjustments may be necessary.

St. John's Wort.Description: St. John's Wort is an herbal remedy that has been used for the treatment of mild to moderate depression. It is believed to work by modulating neurotransmitter activity in the brain.
St. John's Wort.Notes: Should be used with caution as it may interact with other medications, including conventional antidepressants.

Skin Problems (Acne, Eczema, Psoriasis).CategoryDescription: Skin Problems (Acne, Eczema, Psoriasis) include common dermatological conditions that affect the skin, causing inflammation, irritation, and chronic discomfort. Management may involve over-the-counter, prescription, and complementary topical treatments to alleviate symptoms and improve skin appearance.

Benzoyl Peroxide.Description: Benzoyl Peroxide is a topical treatment used primarily for acne. It works by reducing acne-causing bacteria and helping to unclog pores.
Benzoyl Peroxide.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the affected area
Benzoyl Peroxide.Notes: May cause dryness or irritation; using a moisturizer can help mitigate these effects.

Tea Tree Oil.Description: Tea Tree Oil is an herbal remedy known for its antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. When diluted properly with a carrier oil, it may help reduce skin irritation and treat mild forms of acne, eczema, and psoriasis.
Tea Tree Oil.Dosage: Dilute with a carrier oil before application
Tea Tree Oil.Frequency: Apply once or twice daily as needed
Tea Tree Oil.Notes: Perform a patch test before use to ensure no allergic reaction occurs.

Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/H.CategoryDescription: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)/Heartburn involves the reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus, causing a burning sensation in the chest, regurgitation, and sometimes difficulty swallowing. It is commonly managed with lifestyle modifications and medications that reduce stomach acid production.

Omeprazole.Description: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that reduces stomach acid production, alleviating GERD symptoms and promoting healing of the esophagus.
Omeprazole.Maximum: Typically used for up to 8 weeks or as directed by a physician
Omeprazole.Notes: For optimal efficacy, take before meals. Long-term use may require monitoring for potential side effects.
Omeprazole.Alternatives: Esomeprazole, Lansoprazole, or H2 receptor blockers like Famotidine

Ginger.Description: Ginger is an herbal remedy that may help soothe the digestive tract and reduce nausea associated with GERD, although its effectiveness in reducing acid production is less established.
Ginger.Dosage: 500-1000 mg per dose or 1-2 cups of ginger tea
Ginger.Maximum: Follow recommended guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Ginger.Notes: May provide supportive relief for mild symptoms; ensure proper dosage and preparation.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).CategoryDescription: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by chronic abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits, including diarrhea, constipation, or both. Management typically involves dietary modifications, stress reduction, and medications to alleviate symptoms.

Dicyclomine.Description: Dicyclomine is an antispasmodic medication that helps relieve intestinal muscle spasms, thereby reducing abdominal pain and cramping associated with IBS.
Dicyclomine.Maximum: Do not exceed 80 mg per day; follow prescribed guidelines
Dicyclomine.Notes: May cause dry mouth, dizziness, or blurred vision; contraindicated in patients with certain gastrointestinal conditions.
Dicyclomine.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment duration and symptom severity

Peppermint Oil.Description: Peppermint Oil is an herbal remedy with antispasmodic and carminative properties, which can help reduce abdominal pain and bloating in individuals with IBS.
Peppermint Oil.Notes: Enteric-coated formulations are preferred to minimize the risk of heartburn; may cause mild heartburn in some individuals.
Peppermint Oil.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product strength and treatment duration

Peptic Ulcers/Gastric Ulcers.CategoryDescription: Peptic Ulcers, including Gastric Ulcers, are open sores on the inner lining of the stomach or duodenum, most often caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or long-term NSAID use. Treatment focuses on reducing stomach acid production and addressing the underlying cause.

Omeprazole.Description: A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that decreases stomach acid production to promote ulcer healing and alleviate pain.
Omeprazole.Maximum: Typically used for up to 8 weeks; follow prescribed guidelines
Omeprazole.Notes: Often combined with antibiotics if H. pylori infection is confirmed.
Omeprazole.Alternatives: Lansoprazole, Esomeprazole, or H2 receptor blockers (e.g., Famotidine)

Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Description: A licorice extract with glycyrrhizin removed to reduce side effects. It helps soothe and protect the stomach lining, supporting ulcer healing.
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Notes: Best taken on an empty stomach. Consult a healthcare provider if you have high blood pressure or are on other medications.

Anemia.CategoryDescription: Anemia is a condition characterized by a deficiency in red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen transport throughout the body. Common symptoms include fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. Treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, such as iron deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, or chronic disease.

Ferrous Sulfate.Description: Ferrous Sulfate is an iron supplement used to treat iron deficiency anemia by replenishing iron stores essential for red blood cell production.
Ferrous Sulfate.Dosage: Typically 325 mg (providing 65 mg of elemental iron) per tablet
Ferrous Sulfate.Frequency: Once or twice daily, preferably with vitamin C to enhance absorption
Ferrous Sulfate.Maximum: Follow physician's instructions; avoid exceeding recommended doses
Ferrous Sulfate.Notes: Take with food to reduce gastrointestinal upset, but avoid taking with calcium or antacids at the same time to maximize absorption.
Ferrous Sulfate.QuantityNeeded: Depends on severity and duration of treatment

Nettle Leaf.Description: Nettle Leaf is an herbal remedy believed to support blood health due to its rich iron and vitamin content, which may help improve iron levels naturally as part of a balanced diet.
Nettle Leaf.Dosage: 1-2 cups of tea or follow extract label recommendations
Nettle Leaf.Notes: May be used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments; consult a healthcare provider before use, especially if pregnant or on other medications.
Nettle Leaf.Alternatives: Dandelion, Spinach supplements, or other iron-rich herbal formulations

Tea Tree Oil.Dosage: Dilute with a carrier oil to a concentration of about 5%
Tea Tree Oil.Frequency: Apply once or twice daily as needed
Tea Tree Oil.Notes: Perform a patch test before use to check for skin sensitivity; do not apply undiluted oil directly to the skin.
Tea Tree Oil.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product concentration and treatment area size

Sleep Apnea.CategoryDescription: Sleep Apnea is a sleep disorder characterized by repeated episodes of breathing interruption during sleep, which can lead to daytime fatigue, cardiovascular complications, and other health issues. Management typically involves lifestyle modifications, the use of conventional therapies such as CPAP, and complementary approaches to improve sleep quality.

CPAP Therapy.Description: CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) Therapy is the gold standard treatment for moderate to severe sleep apnea. It works by delivering a constant stream of pressurized air through a mask to keep the airway open during sleep.
CPAP Therapy.Dosage: N/A - Pressure settings are individually determined by a titration study
CPAP Therapy.Notes: Consistent nightly use is essential for effectiveness. Pressure settings should be regularly monitored and adjusted by a sleep specialist.
CPAP Therapy.Alternatives: Mandibular Advancement Devices, BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure), surgical interventions, or weight loss programs
CPAP Therapy.Preparation: Setup and use of a CPAP machine with an appropriate mask
CPAP Therapy.QuantityNeeded: One CPAP unit per patient with periodic replacement of filters and accessories as per guidelines

Valerian Root.Description: Valerian Root is an herbal remedy known for its sedative and calming properties. It may help improve overall sleep quality and support relaxation, serving as a complementary approach for individuals with sleep disturbances.
Valerian Root.Dosage: 400-900 mg of standardized extract or 1-2 cups of tea
Valerian Root.Notes: Should be used as a supportive therapy alongside conventional treatments for sleep apnea, not as a primary treatment.
Valerian Root.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS).CategoryDescription: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a neurological disorder characterized by an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, often accompanied by unpleasant sensations. Symptoms typically worsen during periods of inactivity, especially at night, which can disrupt sleep and daily functioning. Management includes conventional medications that modulate dopamine levels along with complementary herbal approaches to promote relaxation and improve sleep quality.
Symptoms: Uncontrollable urge to move the legs
Worsening symptoms during rest or at night

Pramipexole.Description: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist that helps alleviate the symptoms of RLS by stimulating dopamine receptors, thereby improving motor control and reducing discomfort.
Pramipexole.Frequency: Once daily, typically 2-3 hours before bedtime
Pramipexole.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and tolerability
Pramipexole.Notes: May cause side effects such as nausea, dizziness, or sleepiness; dosage adjustments may be necessary based on patient response.
Pramipexole.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment duration and prescription guidelines

Passionflower.Description: Passionflower is an herbal remedy known for its calming and anxiolytic properties. It may help alleviate the restlessness and discomfort associated with RLS by promoting relaxation and enhancing sleep quality.
Passionflower.Dosage: 200-500 mg of standardized extract or 1-2 cups of tea
Passionflower.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Passionflower.Notes: Should be used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments; consult a healthcare provider if taking other sedative medications.
Passionflower.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use

Autoimmune Conditions (e.g., Lupus, vari.CategoryDescription: Autoimmune conditions involve the immune system mistakenly attacking healthy tissues, leading to inflammation, pain, and potential organ damage. Conditions such as Lupus and variants of Rheumatoid Arthritis require management strategies that include immunosuppressive therapies, anti-inflammatory medications, and supportive lifestyle modifications, often complemented by natural therapies.

Hydroxychloroquine.Description: Hydroxychloroquine is an immunomodulatory drug commonly used to manage autoimmune conditions like Lupus and rheumatoid arthritis. It works by modulating the immune response and reducing inflammation, thereby helping to control disease activity.
Hydroxychloroquine.Maximum: Dosage should be tailored to individual patient needs and disease severity
Hydroxychloroquine.Notes: Regular ophthalmologic examinations are recommended due to the risk of retinal toxicity with long-term use.
Hydroxychloroquine.Alternatives: Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine, or corticosteroids for acute flare management
Hydroxychloroquine.QuantityNeeded: Based on prescription guidelines and treatment duration

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric contains curcumin, a bioactive compound with strong anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. It may help reduce joint pain and inflammation in autoimmune conditions when used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: 500-1000 mg of standardized extract per day
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: For enhanced absorption, it is often combined with black pepper extract (piperine). It should be used as an adjunct, not a replacement, for conventional therapy.
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Viral Infections (e.g., COVID-19).CategoryDescription: Viral Infections, such as COVID-19, are caused by viruses that can lead to a range of symptoms from mild respiratory issues to severe systemic illness. Management includes supportive care, antiviral medications for severe cases, and complementary therapies to support the immune system.

Remdesivir.Description: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication that inhibits viral RNA polymerase. It is primarily used in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 to reduce the duration and severity of the illness.
Remdesivir.Dosage: 200 mg IV on Day 1, followed by 100 mg IV daily
Remdesivir.Maximum: Typically administered for 5-10 days, depending on clinical guidelines
Remdesivir.Notes: Requires monitoring of renal and liver function; early administration is crucial for efficacy.
Remdesivir.Alternatives: Other antivirals or supportive therapies such as Dexamethasone in severe cases
Remdesivir.QuantityNeeded: Based on the prescribed course and treatment protocol

Elderberry Extract.Description: Elderberry extract is an herbal remedy traditionally used to support the immune system and combat viral infections. While not a substitute for conventional treatment in severe cases, it may serve as a complementary approach to help alleviate mild symptoms and bolster overall immune health.
Elderberry Extract.Dosage: 300-600 mg of standardized extract per day or as per product guidelines
Elderberry Extract.Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to conventional therapy; consult a healthcare provider for severe cases.
Elderberry Extract.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product concentration and duration of use

Gastroenteritis (acute viral or bacteria.CategoryDescription: Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by acute viral or bacterial infections. It commonly presents with symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. The primary focus of management is to prevent dehydration and restore electrolyte balance through rehydration therapy, with additional measures to control nausea and discomfort when necessary.

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).Description: ORS is used to replenish fluids and essential electrolytes lost during episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. It is the cornerstone of treatment for gastroenteritis, particularly in preventing and managing dehydration.
Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).Dosage: For children: approximately 200-400 ml per hour; for adults, adjust based on fluid losses and clinical guidelines
Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).Frequency: Continuously throughout the day as needed
Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).Maximum: Guidelines based on weight and severity of dehydration
Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).Notes: In cases of severe dehydration, intravenous fluids may be required. Prompt and adequate rehydration is essential for recovery.
Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).QuantityNeeded: Depends on the degree of dehydration and individual requirements

Ginger.Description: Ginger is an herbal remedy with well-known antiemetic properties that may help alleviate nausea and vomiting associated with gastroenteritis. It serves as a complementary approach to support overall symptom management.
Ginger.Dosage: 250-500 mg per dose or 1-2 cups of ginger tea
Ginger.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Ginger.Notes: Ginger should be used in conjunction with proper rehydration measures; it is not a substitute for medical treatment in cases of severe dehydration.
Ginger.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use
Ginger.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)

Rabies.CategoryDescription: Rabies is a viral infection affecting the central nervous system, typically transmitted through the bite of an infected animal. It is almost invariably fatal once symptoms develop, making immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) essential.

Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Description: Rabies PEP is a critical treatment that includes immediate wound cleansing, administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) for passive immunity, and a series of rabies vaccinations to stimulate active immunity. Initiation as soon as possible after exposure is crucial to prevent rabies.
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Dosage: Rabies Vaccine: 0.5-1.0 mL per dose (IM) on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 (plus an additional dose on day 28 for immunocompromised patients); Rabies Immunoglobulin: 20 IU/kg body weight on day 0, infiltrated around the wound
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Frequency: Multiple injections as per the established PEP schedule
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Maximum: Dosage follows established guidelines based on exposure risk and patient factors
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Notes: Immediate initiation of PEP is vital. Completing the full treatment course is mandatory to prevent the onset of rabies.
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).Alternatives: No effective alternatives; prompt PEP is the only proven intervention following exposure.
Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP).QuantityNeeded: Determined by patient weight and vaccination schedule

Andrographis Paniculata.Description: Andrographis paniculata is an herb with antiviral and immunomodulatory properties. However, there is no scientific evidence supporting its use for preventing or treating rabies, and it should never replace conventional post-exposure prophylaxis.
Andrographis Paniculata.Dosage: 400-600 mg per day of standardized extract
Andrographis Paniculata.Notes: This herbal remedy is provided for informational purposes only. Rabies is a medical emergency that requires immediate conventional treatment.
Andrographis Paniculata.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and treatment duration

TB (Tuberculosis).CategoryDescription: Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs, leading to symptoms such as chronic cough, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Management involves a long course of multiple antibiotics to eradicate the bacteria and prevent drug resistance, along with supportive care to manage symptoms.

Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.Description: This first-line anti-tuberculosis regimen involves a combination of four antibiotics administered during an intensive phase, followed by a continuation phase with fewer drugs. It is designed to eliminate Mycobacterium tuberculosis and prevent the development of drug resistance.
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.Dosage: Isoniazid 300 mg, Rifampin 600 mg, Pyrazinamide 1500-2000 mg, Ethambutol 1200 mg (daily dosages vary based on patient weight and clinical guidelines)
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.Frequency: Daily during the intensive phase (first 2 months), then typically Isoniazid and Rifampin daily for an additional 4 months
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.Maximum: Dosages should be tailored to individual patient weight and monitored by a healthcare provider
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.Notes: Strict adherence to the regimen is essential to prevent drug resistance and relapse. Regular monitoring of liver function and patient adherence is required.
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and patient-specific dosing
Isoniazid-Rifampin-Pyrazinamide-Ethambut.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)

Tulsi (Holy Basil).Description: Tulsi (Holy Basil) is an herb used in traditional medicine for its immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory properties. It may offer supportive benefits in improving respiratory health and boosting the immune system, but should not replace conventional TB therapy.
Tulsi (Holy Basil).Dosage: 300-500 mg of standardized extract per day or 1-2 cups of tea
Tulsi (Holy Basil).Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Tulsi (Holy Basil).Notes: Used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional TB treatment. It does not cure TB and should only be considered supportive.
Tulsi (Holy Basil).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use

HIV/AIDS.CategoryDescription: HIV/AIDS is a chronic viral infection caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which progressively damages the immune system. Without treatment, HIV can advance to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), leaving individuals vulnerable to opportunistic infections and certain cancers. Management relies on lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) to suppress viral replication, maintain immune function, and reduce the risk of transmission. While complementary therapies may support overall health, they are not substitutes for ART.

Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Description: ART is the cornerstone of HIV/AIDS management. It involves a combination of antiretroviral drugs that work synergistically to reduce the viral load to undetectable levels, preserve immune function, and prevent disease progression and transmission.
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Dosage: Regimen-specific; common regimens include two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as Tenofovir and Emtricitabine, plus an agent from another class (e.g., an NNRTI, protease inhibitor, or integrase inhibitor like Dolutegravir)
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Frequency: Typically once daily or as per the specific regimen
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Maximum: Dosages are individualized based on clinical guidelines and patient-specific factors
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Notes: Strict adherence is essential to prevent drug resistance and treatment failure. Regular monitoring of viral load and CD4 counts is crucial.
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).Alternatives: Alternative regimens are available for patients with drug resistance or intolerable side effects
Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).QuantityNeeded: Determined by the specific regimen and treatment duration

Garlic.Description: Garlic is an herbal supplement known for its antimicrobial and antioxidant properties, and it is sometimes used to support immune health. However, current evidence does not support its use as a primary treatment for HIV/AIDS, and it may interact with antiretroviral medications.
Garlic.Dosage: 300-1000 mg per day of standardized extract, or as per product guidelines
Garlic.Notes: Should only be used as a complementary supplement alongside conventional ART. Consult a healthcare provider prior to use due to potential interactions with antiretroviral drugs.
Garlic.Alternatives: Other immune-supportive supplements may be considered, but none should replace standard ART
Garlic.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use

These conditions are marked by recurrent episodes of inflammation that result in symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. Management focuses on inducing and maintaining remission using anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive therapies, along with dietary adjustments and lifestyle modifications.

Mesalamine.Description: Mesalamine is an anti-inflammatory agent used to treat mild to moderate Ulcerative Colitis and to maintain remission in IBD by reducing inflammation in the colon.

Mesalamine.Frequency: Divided doses throughout the day as prescribed
Mesalamine.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and tolerability
Mesalamine.Notes: Regular monitoring of kidney function and gastrointestinal tolerance is recommended; side effects may include headache and abdominal discomfort.

Boswellia Serrata.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Boswellia Serrata.Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to standard therapy; potential benefits include reduced inflammation and symptom relief.

Boswellia Serrata.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product guidelines and duration of use

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD).CategoryDescription: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function, typically indicated by a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and the presence of proteinuria. This condition increases the risk of cardiovascular complications, electrolyte imbalances, anemia, and bone mineral disorders. Management focuses on slowing disease progression, controlling blood pressure, managing complications, and implementing dietary and lifestyle modifications.

ACE Inhibitor (Lisinopril).Description: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to lower blood pressure, reduce proteinuria, and slow the progression of CKD by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II.

ACE Inhibitor (Lisinopril).Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on clinical guidelines and patient response
ACE Inhibitor (Lisinopril).Notes: Regular monitoring of kidney function and serum potassium is essential. Contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.
ACE Inhibitor (Lisinopril).Alternatives: Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) such as Losartan
ACE Inhibitor (Lisinopril).QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and patient-specific dosing

Astragalus.Description: Astragalus membranaceus is an herb used in traditional medicine to support kidney function and reduce proteinuria. It is considered a complementary therapy and should not replace conventional treatment for CKD.
Astragalus.Dosage: 500-1000 mg of standardized extract per day, or as directed by product guidelines
Astragalus.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Astragalus.Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to conventional therapies. Consult a healthcare provider before use, as herbal supplements may interact with prescribed medications.
Astragalus.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Viral Hepatitis (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepa.CategoryDescription: Viral Hepatitis refers to liver inflammation caused by viral infections, primarily Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C. These infections can lead to chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and an increased risk of liver cancer. Management focuses on antiviral therapy to reduce viral replication and prevent liver damage, along with regular monitoring of liver function.

Antiviral Therapy (e.g., Tenofovir for H.Maximum: Dosages are individualized based on patient weight, liver function, and clinical guidelines

Milk Thistle.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Milk Thistle.Notes: Used as a complementary therapy to support liver function; it should not replace conventional antiviral treatment.

Erectile Dysfunction.CategoryDescription: Erectile Dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sexual performance. It can result from vascular, neurological, hormonal, or psychological factors. Management typically involves lifestyle modifications, pharmacotherapy, and, in some cases, complementary therapies.

Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa.CategoryDescription: Eating Disorders, including Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa, are serious psychiatric conditions characterized by abnormal eating behaviors, distorted body image, and significant emotional distress. These disorders can lead to severe physical complications such as malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiac issues. Management requires a comprehensive, multidisciplinary approach involving psychological therapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and sometimes pharmacotherapy.

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).Description: CBT is a structured, evidence-based psychotherapy that helps individuals identify and modify dysfunctional thoughts and behaviors related to food, body image, and self-worth. It is considered a first-line treatment for eating disorders.
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).Maximum: Duration varies based on individual progress
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).Notes: Often combined with nutritional counseling and family-based therapy for adolescents.

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors.Notes: Regular follow-up is necessary to monitor efficacy and side effects.

Certain Cancers (e.g., Breast Cancer, Pr.CategoryDescription: Certain cancers, such as breast, prostate, and colorectal cancer, are malignant conditions characterized by uncontrolled cell growth. Management typically involves a multimodal approach that may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy, and targeted treatments. Early detection and a combination of conventional treatments are critical for improving survival rates and quality of life.

Chemotherapy.Description: Chemotherapy involves the use of cytotoxic drugs to target rapidly dividing cancer cells. It is often used in combination with surgery, radiation, or targeted therapies to reduce tumor size, prevent recurrence, or manage advanced disease.

Chemotherapy.Maximum: Dosages are individualized based on patient tolerance and clinical protocols

Peripheral Vascular Disease.CategoryDescription: Peripheral Vascular Disease (PVD) is a circulatory disorder characterized by the narrowing of blood vessels outside the heart and brain, most commonly affecting the legs. Management typically involves lifestyle modifications, pharmacotherapy, and in some cases, surgical intervention to improve circulation.

Cilostazol.Description: Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that improves symptoms of intermittent claudication by inhibiting platelet aggregation and dilating blood vessels, thereby enhancing blood flow to the affected limbs.

Ginkgo Biloba.Description: Ginkgo Biloba is an herbal supplement that may enhance peripheral circulation through vasodilation and antioxidant effects. It is used as a complementary therapy to help alleviate symptoms of intermittent claudication in PVD.

Ginkgo Biloba.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider

Acute Pancreatitis.CategoryDescription: Acute Pancreatitis is a sudden inflammation of the pancreas that can result from gallstones, alcohol abuse, or other causes. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and systemic inflammatory responses. Management focuses on supportive care, including aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain management, and bowel rest, with careful monitoring for complications.

IV Fluid Therapy.Description: Aggressive intravenous fluid replacement is essential in acute pancreatitis to maintain circulatory volume, prevent hypovolemia, and reduce the risk of organ failure. Fluid therapy is tailored based on the patient's hemodynamic status and electrolyte balance.

IV Fluid Therapy.Maximum: Determined by patient fluid status and clinical judgment
IV Fluid Therapy.Notes: Close monitoring of vital signs, urine output, and electrolyte levels is critical to avoid fluid overload or under-resuscitation.

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric, which contains the active compound curcumin, exhibits anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. While not recommended during the acute phase, it may be considered as a complementary therapy during recovery to help reduce inflammation.

Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Not indicated for use during the acute phase of pancreatitis; consult a healthcare provider before use, as it should only be integrated into the recovery plan after stabilization.

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).CategoryDescription: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric condition that can develop following exposure to a traumatic event. Management typically involves evidence-based psychotherapies, pharmacotherapy, and complementary interventions aimed at reducing symptoms and improving overall functioning.

Oxybutynin.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and tolerability
Oxybutynin.Notes: Common side effects include dry mouth, constipation, and blurred vision. Extended-release formulations may help reduce these side effects.
Oxybutynin.Alternatives: Other antimuscarinics (e.g., Tolterodine, Solifenacin) or beta-3 adrenergic agonists (e.g., Mirabegron)
Oxybutynin.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and patient-specific dosing

Pumpkin Seed Extract.Description: Pumpkin Seed Extract is believed to support bladder health and may help reduce urinary frequency and improve bladder control. It is used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments.
Pumpkin Seed Extract.Dosage: 100-200 mg per day of standardized extract
Pumpkin Seed Extract.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Pumpkin Seed Extract.Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to lifestyle modifications and conventional therapies. Consult with a healthcare provider prior to use.
Pumpkin Seed Extract.Alternatives: Saw Palmetto or other herbal supplements aimed at supporting urinary function
Pumpkin Seed Extract.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD).CategoryDescription: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a progressive condition characterized by the gradual loss of kidney function over time. This leads to the accumulation of waste products, fluid imbalances, and electrolyte disturbances. Management focuses on slowing disease progression, controlling contributing factors such as hypertension and diabetes, and preventing complications through lifestyle modifications, pharmacologic therapies, and, in advanced stages, renal replacement interventions.

ACE Inhibitors.Description: ACE inhibitors help manage CKD by lowering blood pressure and reducing proteinuria, thereby decreasing the strain on the kidneys. They are essential in slowing the progression of kidney damage, particularly in patients with diabetic nephropathy or hypertension.
ACE Inhibitors.Dosage: Typically 5-20 mg once daily, adjusted based on blood pressure and kidney function
ACE Inhibitors.Maximum: Dosage should be titrated according to patient response and renal function monitoring
ACE Inhibitors.Notes: Regular monitoring of kidney function and serum potassium is essential; contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.
ACE Inhibitors.Alternatives: Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) such as Losartan
ACE Inhibitors.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment regimen and refill schedule
ACE Inhibitors.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as needed)

Astragalus Membranaceus.Description: Astragalus membranaceus is an herb traditionally used in Chinese medicine believed to support kidney function and reduce inflammation. It may help lower proteinuria and improve overall renal health when used as an adjunct to conventional therapy.
Astragalus Membranaceus.Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Astragalus Membranaceus.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Astragalus Membranaceus.Notes: Should be used as a complementary treatment alongside conventional therapies; clinical evidence is variable and further research is warranted.
Astragalus Membranaceus.Alternatives: Cordyceps or other renal-supportive herbal supplements
Astragalus Membranaceus.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD.CategoryDescription: Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) is characterized by the accumulation of excess fat in the liver in individuals who consume little to no alcohol. It is closely associated with obesity, insulin resistance, and metabolic syndrome. While many cases remain benign, NAFLD can progress to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), fibrosis, and cirrhosis. Management primarily focuses on lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and increased physical activity, with pharmacologic and complementary therapies playing a supportive role in reducing liver inflammation and oxidative stress.

Vitamin E.Description: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that may help reduce liver inflammation and oxidative damage in patients with NAFLD, particularly in non-diabetic individuals with biopsy-proven NASH.
Vitamin E.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient needs and risk factors
Vitamin E.Notes: Long-term use should be monitored for potential adverse effects; lifestyle modifications remain the cornerstone of management.
Vitamin E.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment duration and clinical response

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric, and specifically its active compound curcumin, possesses anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that may support liver health and help reduce fat accumulation in the liver when used as a complementary therapy.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Should be used as an adjunct to lifestyle modifications and conventional therapies; individual response may vary.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Alternatives: Milk Thistle or Omega-3 Fatty Acids
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).CategoryDescription: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in the deep veins, most commonly in the legs. These clots can cause leg pain, swelling, and redness, and may lead to serious complications such as pulmonary embolism if they dislodge and travel to the lungs. Management focuses on anticoagulation to prevent clot extension and embolization, along with supportive measures such as compression therapy and risk factor modification.

Enoxaparin.Description: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin used as an anticoagulant to prevent and treat deep vein thrombosis. It works by inhibiting clot formation and is typically used in the acute management phase of DVT.
Enoxaparin.Dosage: Typically 1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours for treatment, or 40 mg once daily for prophylaxis
Enoxaparin.Maximum: Dose should be individualized based on patient weight, renal function, and bleeding risk
Enoxaparin.Notes: Regular monitoring of renal function, platelet counts, and signs of bleeding is essential. Transition to oral anticoagulants may be considered after the initial treatment phase.
Enoxaparin.Alternatives: Unfractionated Heparin or Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Rivaroxaban or Apixaban
Enoxaparin.QuantityNeeded: Based on patient weight, dosing regimen, and treatment duration
Enoxaparin.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as needed)

Garlic (Allium sativum).Description: Garlic (Allium sativum) is an herbal remedy traditionally recognized for its potential antithrombotic and cardiovascular benefits. It is thought to help support healthy blood flow and reduce platelet aggregation when used as a complementary approach.
Garlic (Allium sativum).Dosage: 600-1200 mg per day of standardized extract
Garlic (Allium sativum).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Garlic (Allium sativum).Notes: This herbal option is intended as a complementary therapy and should not replace conventional anticoagulation. Caution is advised due to potential increased bleeding risk when combined with other blood thinners.
Garlic (Allium sativum).Alternatives: Ginkgo biloba may provide similar blood flow support
Garlic (Allium sativum).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Pulmonary Embolism (PE).CategoryDescription: Pulmonary Embolism (PE) is a life-threatening condition in which one or more arteries in the lungs become obstructed by a blood clot, often originating from deep vein thrombosis in the legs. This obstruction can cause sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid heart rate, and in severe cases, cardiovascular collapse. Management focuses on rapid anticoagulation to prevent further clot formation, thrombolytic therapy in severe cases, and supportive measures to stabilize the patient.

Heparin.Description: Heparin, including unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin, is used to quickly anticoagulate patients with pulmonary embolism. It works by preventing the extension of existing clots and the formation of new ones, serving as an essential component in the acute management of PE.
Heparin.Dosage: Dosing is weight-based; typically, an initial bolus is administered followed by a continuous infusion or scheduled subcutaneous injections
Heparin.Frequency: Continuous infusion or as per prescribed dosing schedule
Heparin.Maximum: Dosage should be tailored according to patient weight, renal function, and coagulation test results
Heparin.Notes: Frequent monitoring of aPTT or anti-Xa levels is necessary; after stabilization, patients are often transitioned to oral anticoagulants for long-term management.
Heparin.Alternatives: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (e.g., Enoxaparin) or Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Rivaroxaban or Apixaban
Heparin.QuantityNeeded: Determined by patient weight, treatment protocol, and duration of therapy
Heparin.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as needed)
