Ginger.Description: Ginger is an herbal remedy known for its anti-inflammatory and potential antithrombotic properties. It may help support circulatory health and complement conventional therapies by aiding in the prevention of clot formation when used as an adjunct.
Ginger.Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Ginger.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ginger.Notes: Ginger should be used as a supportive therapy and not as a substitute for standard anticoagulation; caution is advised when used concurrently with blood-thinning medications due to the potential for increased bleeding risk.
Ginger.Alternatives: Turmeric or Garlic supplements may offer similar complementary benefits
Ginger.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Sepsis.CategoryDescription: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition characterized by a dysregulated immune response to infection, leading to systemic inflammation, tissue damage, and potentially multi-organ failure. Prompt recognition and treatment are essential, with management strategies including early administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, aggressive fluid resuscitation, and supportive care such as vasopressor therapy when necessary.

Meropenem.Description: Meropenem is a broad-spectrum beta-lactam antibiotic used in the initial management of sepsis to cover a wide range of bacterial pathogens. Early administration is critical to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with sepsis.
Meropenem.Dosage: Typically 1 g every 8 hours, adjusted based on the severity of infection and renal function
Meropenem.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and renal function
Meropenem.Notes: Early and appropriate antibiotic therapy is paramount; antibiotic regimens may be adjusted based on culture results and clinical evolution. Combination therapy may be warranted in complex cases.
Meropenem.Alternatives: Other broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin/Tazobactam or Imipenem/Cilastatin
Meropenem.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the treatment protocol and duration of therapy
Meropenem.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as needed)

Andrographis Paniculata.Description: Andrographis paniculata is an herbal remedy known for its potential anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties. It may help support the immune system and modulate the inflammatory response, serving as a complementary therapy in the context of infections.
Andrographis Paniculata.Dosage: 400-600 mg per day of standardized extract
Andrographis Paniculata.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Andrographis Paniculata.Notes: Intended as an adjunct to, not a replacement for, conventional sepsis treatment. Clinical evidence is limited and it should be used under professional guidance, particularly in severe infections.
Andrographis Paniculata.Alternatives: Echinacea or Elderberry supplements may offer similar immune-supportive benefits
Andrographis Paniculata.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Celiac Disease.CategoryDescription: Celiac Disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. In genetically predisposed individuals, exposure to gluten leads to an immune-mediated inflammatory response that damages the small intestine, resulting in malabsorption of nutrients and a range of gastrointestinal and systemic symptoms. Management focuses on strict adherence to a gluten-free diet, along with nutritional supplementation and supportive care to address any deficiencies and promote intestinal healing.

Gluten-Free Diet.Description: A strict, lifelong gluten-free diet is the cornerstone of managing celiac disease. This involves eliminating all gluten-containing grains from the diet to allow the small intestine to heal and to prevent further immune-mediated damage.
Gluten-Free Diet.Dosage: Not applicable â€“ requires adherence with every meal
Gluten-Free Diet.Notes: Complete avoidance of gluten is essential for symptom resolution and to prevent long-term complications. Nutritional assessments and supplementation (e.g., iron, calcium, vitamin D) may be necessary to address deficiencies.
Gluten-Free Diet.Alternatives: Nutritional supplements as needed based on individual deficiency profiles
Gluten-Free Diet.QuantityNeeded: Varies based on individual dietary requirements

Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).Description: Slippery Elm is derived from the inner bark of the slippery elm tree and is known for its mucilaginous properties that help soothe and protect the gastrointestinal tract. It may provide symptomatic relief by coating the lining of the gut and reducing irritation.
Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).Dosage: 400-800 mg per day of standardized extract or 1-2 teaspoons of powder, taken two to three times daily
Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).Maximum: Dosage should be adjusted according to product guidelines and individual tolerance
Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support gut healing in conjunction with a gluten-free diet. It does not replace the need for strict dietary management. Consult a healthcare provider before beginning any new supplement.
Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).Alternatives: Marshmallow root or Aloe Vera supplements (with caution)
Slippery Elm (Ulmus rubra).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Diverticulitis.CategoryDescription: Diverticulitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. This condition often presents with abdominal pain (typically in the lower left quadrant), fever, and changes in bowel habits. Management strategies focus on reducing inflammation, controlling infection with antibiotics, and promoting bowel rest. In severe or recurrent cases, hospitalization or surgical intervention may be necessary. Dietary modifications, particularly increasing fiber intake once the acute phase resolves, are essential to prevent future episodes.

Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Description: A combination of ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, and metronidazole, an anti-anaerobic agent, is commonly used to treat uncomplicated diverticulitis. This regimen targets both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria implicated in the infection.
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Dosage: Ciprofloxacin: 500 mg twice daily; Metronidazole: 500 mg three times daily
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Frequency: Typically administered for 7-10 days, depending on clinical response
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Maximum: Dosage should be adjusted based on patient renal function and overall tolerance
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Notes: For severe cases or complications, intravenous antibiotics and hospital admission may be required. Treatment should always be guided by current clinical guidelines and tailored to individual patient needs.
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.Alternatives: Amoxicillin-Clavulanate may be used as an alternative regimen
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the duration of therapy and prescribing guidelines
Ciprofloxacin/Metronidazole Combination.AgeGroup: Adults (with adjustments for pediatric patients as necessary)

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric contains curcumin, a natural compound with anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. When used as a complementary therapy, it may help reduce colonic inflammation and support the healing process in diverticulitis.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments and dietary management. It is not a substitute for antibiotics in the active treatment of infection.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Alternatives: Boswellia Serrata or Ginger supplements may offer similar anti-inflammatory benefits
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Hemorrhoids.CategoryDescription: Hemorrhoids are swollen and inflamed veins located in the lower rectum and anus, which can cause discomfort, pain, itching, and bleeding. Management typically includes both conservative measures and medical treatments aimed at reducing inflammation, easing symptoms, and preventing recurrence. Lifestyle modifications, such as increasing dietary fiber and fluid intake, are also essential for long-term relief and prevention.

Hydrocortisone Cream.Description: Hydrocortisone cream is a topical corticosteroid used to alleviate inflammation, itching, and pain associated with hemorrhoids. It helps reduce swelling and irritation in the affected area.
Hydrocortisone Cream.Dosage: Apply a thin layer to the affected area up to 3-4 times daily
Hydrocortisone Cream.Maximum: Use as directed; prolonged use may lead to skin thinning or irritation
Hydrocortisone Cream.Notes: For best results, use in conjunction with lifestyle modifications such as a high-fiber diet and adequate hydration. Consult a healthcare provider if symptoms persist.
Hydrocortisone Cream.Alternatives: Other topical treatments such as analgesic creams or witch hazel pads
Hydrocortisone Cream.QuantityNeeded: Depends on treatment duration and product size
Hydrocortisone Cream.Availability: OTC or Prescription (depending on formulation and concentration)

Witch Hazel.Description: Witch hazel is an astringent derived from the witch hazel plant. It has anti-inflammatory and soothing properties that help reduce irritation, swelling, and discomfort associated with hemorrhoids.
Witch Hazel.Dosage: Apply to the affected area as needed, typically after bowel movements
Witch Hazel.Maximum: Follow product guidelines or consult a healthcare provider
Witch Hazel.Notes: Often used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments; ensure the product is suitable for sensitive skin.
Witch Hazel.Alternatives: Aloe Vera gel may also provide soothing relief
Witch Hazel.QuantityNeeded: Depends on individual usage and product formulation

Urinary Incontinence.CategoryDescription: Urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine, which can result from various factors such as bladder dysfunction, weakened pelvic floor muscles, or neurological conditions. It encompasses several types, including stress, urge, overflow, and functional incontinence. Management strategies focus on identifying the underlying cause and may include behavioral modifications, pelvic floor exercises, medications, and, in some cases, surgical interventions.

Oxybutynin.Description: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication that relaxes the bladder's smooth muscle, helping to reduce symptoms such as urinary urgency, frequency, and urge incontinence. It is commonly prescribed to manage overactive bladder symptoms.
Oxybutynin.Form: Tablet, Extended-release Tablet, or Transdermal Patch
Oxybutynin.Dosage: Typically 5 mg two to three times daily for immediate-release formulations, or 10-15 mg once daily for extended-release formulations
Oxybutynin.Frequency: Multiple times daily for immediate-release; once daily for extended-release
Oxybutynin.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient tolerance and clinical response; maximum limits depend on the specific formulation
Oxybutynin.Notes: Monitor for anticholinergic side effects such as dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, and potential cognitive effects, especially in elderly patients. Dosage adjustments may be necessary based on patient age and comorbidities.
Oxybutynin.Alternatives: Tolterodine, Solifenacin, or other antimuscarinic agents
Oxybutynin.Preparation: Oral for tablets; transdermal for patch formulations
Oxybutynin.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the prescribed dosing regimen and treatment duration
Oxybutynin.AgeGroup: Adults (with caution and dose adjustments in elderly patients)

Saw Palmetto.Description: Saw Palmetto is an herbal extract derived from the berries of the saw palmetto plant. It is believed to support urinary tract health by reducing inflammation and potentially improving bladder function, which may help alleviate symptoms of urinary incontinence, particularly in cases related to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
Saw Palmetto.Dosage: 160-320 mg per day of standardized extract
Saw Palmetto.Frequency: Once daily or divided into multiple doses according to product guidelines
Saw Palmetto.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product recommendations or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Saw Palmetto.Notes: While primarily used for prostate-related urinary symptoms, Saw Palmetto may also provide complementary support for urinary incontinence. It is intended to be an adjunct to conventional treatment, not a substitute.
Saw Palmetto.Alternatives: Pumpkin Seed Extract, which may offer similar urinary tract support
Saw Palmetto.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration
Saw Palmetto.Sex: Both (though more commonly used in men for prostate-related issues)

Endometriosis.CategoryDescription: Endometriosis is a chronic gynecological condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterine cavity. This ectopic endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes, leading to inflammation, pain, and the formation of scar tissue. Common symptoms include pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and, in some cases, infertility. Management strategies focus on pain relief, hormonal regulation, and, when necessary, surgical intervention to remove ectopic tissue.

Leuprolide Acetate.Description: Leuprolide Acetate is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that creates a temporary hypoestrogenic state, reducing the stimulation of endometrial tissue growth and alleviating pain associated with endometriosis.
Leuprolide Acetate.Dosage: Typically 3.75 mg monthly or 11.25 mg every three months, depending on the formulation
Leuprolide Acetate.Frequency: Monthly or every three months as prescribed
Leuprolide Acetate.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and side effects
Leuprolide Acetate.Notes: Patients may experience menopausal-like symptoms due to reduced estrogen levels; add-back therapy may be considered to mitigate side effects. Regular monitoring of bone density is recommended during long-term use.
Leuprolide Acetate.Alternatives: Other hormonal therapies such as combined oral contraceptives, progestins, or GnRH antagonists
Leuprolide Acetate.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and prescribed regimen

Vitex Agnus-Castus.Description: Vitex Agnus-Castus, commonly known as chasteberry, is an herbal remedy traditionally used to help balance hormonal levels. It may alleviate symptoms of endometriosis by modulating the production of prolactin and other reproductive hormones.
Vitex Agnus-Castus.Dosage: 20-40 mg per day of standardized extract
Vitex Agnus-Castus.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined by a healthcare provider
Vitex Agnus-Castus.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support hormonal balance and reduce inflammation. It should not replace conventional treatments, and consultation with a healthcare provider is advised.
Vitex Agnus-Castus.Alternatives: Curcumin or Omega-3 Fatty Acids, which may also help reduce inflammation
Vitex Agnus-Castus.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Infertility.CategoryDescription: Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular, unprotected intercourse. It can result from a variety of factors including hormonal imbalances, structural abnormalities, or unexplained causes. Management involves a comprehensive evaluation to identify the underlying issues, followed by lifestyle modifications, medical therapies, and assisted reproductive technologies as needed.
Symptoms: Inability to conceive after 12 months of regular, unprotected intercourse
Low sperm count or poor sperm quality in men

Clomiphene Citrate.Description: Clomiphene Citrate is a first-line ovulation induction agent used to stimulate the release of hormones necessary for ovulation. It is commonly prescribed for women with ovulatory dysfunction who are experiencing infertility.
Clomiphene Citrate.Dosage: Typically 50 mg daily for 5 days, starting between days 2-5 of the menstrual cycle
Clomiphene Citrate.Maximum: Dosage may be increased up to 150 mg daily if ovulatory response is insufficient
Clomiphene Citrate.Notes: Ovulation should be monitored through ultrasound or ovulation predictor kits; possible side effects include hot flashes, mood swings, and visual disturbances. Treatment is generally limited to a few cycles before re-evaluation.
Clomiphene Citrate.Alternatives: Letrozole or injectable gonadotropins may be used as alternative ovulation induction agents
Clomiphene Citrate.QuantityNeeded: Depends on the number of treatment cycles and the prescribed dosing regimen

Maca Root.Description: Maca Root is an adaptogenic herb traditionally used to support reproductive health by balancing hormonal levels and enhancing fertility in both men and women. It is believed to improve energy, stamina, and overall endocrine function.
Maca Root.Dosage: Typically 1500-3000 mg per day of standardized extract, divided into two or three doses
Maca Root.Maximum: Dosage should follow product-specific recommendations or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Maca Root.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support fertility; it should not replace conventional treatments. Individual responses may vary, and it is best used as part of a broader approach to reproductive health.
Maca Root.Alternatives: Tribulus Terrestris or Vitex Agnus-Castus, which may also aid in hormonal balance
Maca Root.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use
Maca Root.AgeGroup: Adults (both men and women of reproductive age)

Bipolar Disorder.CategoryDescription: Bipolar Disorder is a chronic mental health condition characterized by alternating episodes of mania (or hypomania) and depression. These mood fluctuations can significantly impact energy levels, behavior, and overall functioning. Management typically involves a combination of pharmacologic treatments, psychotherapy, lifestyle modifications, and regular monitoring to stabilize mood and prevent relapses.

Lithium Carbonate.Description: Lithium Carbonate is a mood stabilizer considered a first-line treatment for Bipolar Disorder. It helps reduce the frequency and severity of both manic and depressive episodes by modulating neurotransmitter activity.
Lithium Carbonate.Dosage: Typically 300-600 mg per dose, taken two to three times daily; dosage is adjusted based on serum lithium levels
Lithium Carbonate.Frequency: Multiple times daily, as determined by therapeutic monitoring
Lithium Carbonate.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized according to serum levels and patient response
Lithium Carbonate.Notes: Regular monitoring of blood lithium levels, renal function, and thyroid function is essential due to the narrow therapeutic index. Patients must be educated on signs of toxicity, such as tremors, excessive thirst, and confusion.
Lithium Carbonate.Alternatives: Valproate, Carbamazepine, Lamotrigine, or atypical antipsychotics may be used based on individual patient profiles and episode characteristics
Lithium Carbonate.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment protocol and monitoring requirements

Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Description: Omega-3 Fatty Acids, particularly EPA and DHA, are essential fats that may offer mood-stabilizing and anti-inflammatory benefits. They have been studied as an adjunctive treatment to help alleviate depressive symptoms in Bipolar Disorder.
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Dosage: Typically 1000-3000 mg per day of combined EPA and DHA
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Frequency: Once daily or divided into multiple doses as preferred
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatment. Consultation with a healthcare provider is recommended, especially for individuals on blood-thinning medications.
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.Alternatives: N-Acetyl Cysteine (NAC) or S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAMe) have also been explored for mood support in Bipolar Disorder
Omega-3 Fatty Acids.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Schizophrenia.CategoryDescription: Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by disturbances in thought, perception, and behavior. Symptoms may include delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and impaired cognitive function, which can significantly impact social and occupational functioning. Management typically involves long-term antipsychotic medication, psychotherapy, and supportive services to help manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Risperidone.Description: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia by modulating dopamine and serotonin receptors, thereby reducing psychotic symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations.
Risperidone.Dosage: Typically 1-6 mg per day, titrated based on clinical response and side effects
Risperidone.Frequency: Once or twice daily, as prescribed
Risperidone.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized with careful monitoring to minimize adverse effects
Risperidone.Notes: Regular monitoring for side effects including weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and extrapyramidal symptoms is essential. Risperidone is part of a comprehensive treatment plan that includes psychosocial interventions.
Risperidone.Alternatives: Other atypical antipsychotics such as Olanzapine, Quetiapine, or Aripiprazole may be considered based on patient needs
Risperidone.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment regimen and duration

Ginkgo Biloba.Description: Ginkgo Biloba is an herbal supplement that has been explored for its potential cognitive and neuroprotective benefits. It may help improve cognitive function and support overall brain health as an adjunctive therapy in schizophrenia.
Ginkgo Biloba.Dosage: Typically 120-240 mg per day of standardized extract
Ginkgo Biloba.Frequency: Once or twice daily, according to product guidelines
Ginkgo Biloba.Maximum: Dosage should follow product recommendations or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ginkgo Biloba.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy alongside conventional antipsychotic treatment. It should not replace primary medications, and its benefits may vary among individuals.
Ginkgo Biloba.Alternatives: Omega-3 Fatty Acids or Ashwagandha may also be considered as supportive adjuncts for mental health
Ginkgo Biloba.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS).CategoryDescription: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is a common condition resulting from compression of the median nerve at the wrist, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, pain, and weakness in the hand. Management strategies include conservative approaches like rest, wrist splinting, and anti-inflammatory medications, with more advanced interventions such as corticosteroid injections or surgical decompression reserved for severe or refractory cases.
Symptoms: Pain in the wrist and hand

Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Description: Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection is a corticosteroid treatment used to reduce inflammation and swelling in the carpal tunnel. By decreasing local inflammation, it alleviates pressure on the median nerve, thereby relieving pain and improving function.
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Dosage: Typically 10-40 mg per injection, adjusted based on the severity of symptoms
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Frequency: Usually administered as a single injection with the option for repeat injections after several weeks if needed
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Maximum: Injections are generally limited to one or two per year to minimize potential side effects
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Notes: This treatment is considered when conservative measures fail to provide adequate relief. Ultrasound guidance may be used for precise delivery, and patients should be monitored for local adverse effects such as pain or infection.
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.Alternatives: Oral NSAIDs, wrist splinting, or surgical decompression in cases of severe or persistent symptoms
Triamcinolone Acetonide Injection.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the individual treatment plan and severity of symptoms

Capsaicin Cream.Description: Capsaicin Cream is derived from chili peppers and works by depleting substance P, a neuropeptide involved in pain transmission. This reduction in substance P helps to alleviate the neuropathic pain associated with Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.
Capsaicin Cream.Dosage: Apply a pea-sized amount to the affected area 3-4 times daily
Capsaicin Cream.Frequency: 3-4 times daily, or as directed on the product label
Capsaicin Cream.Maximum: Use as directed to avoid excessive skin irritation
Capsaicin Cream.Notes: An initial burning or stinging sensation may occur with application. Consistent use over several weeks is typically necessary for maximum benefit. This topical remedy is intended as an adjunct to, not a replacement for, conventional treatments.
Capsaicin Cream.Alternatives: Topical NSAIDs or herbal anti-inflammatory remedies such as Arnica
Capsaicin Cream.QuantityNeeded: Depends on the product formulation and duration of use

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARD.CategoryDescription: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a severe, life-threatening condition characterized by rapid onset of diffuse alveolar damage and widespread inflammation in the lungs. This leads to impaired gas exchange and refractory hypoxemia. ARDS often develops secondary to conditions such as pneumonia, sepsis, trauma, or aspiration. Management focuses on supportive care with strategies to optimize oxygenation and minimize further lung injury, while addressing the underlying cause.

Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Description: Mechanical ventilation using lung-protective strategies is the cornerstone of ARDS management. This approach involves using low tidal volumes and individualized positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) settings to reduce ventilator-induced lung injury while maintaining adequate oxygenation.
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Dosage: Tidal volume typically set at 4-8 mL/kg of predicted body weight; PEEP adjusted based on oxygenation targets
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Maximum: Ventilator settings are titrated based on blood gas analyses and patient response
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Notes: This treatment is delivered in an intensive care setting with constant monitoring. Adjunctive therapies such as prone positioning, neuromuscular blockade, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may be considered in severe or refractory cases.
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Alternatives: High-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) or ECMO in select cases
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.Preparation: ICU-based support with specialized ventilator equipment
Mechanical Ventilation with Lung-Protect.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the severity of ARDS and the duration of mechanical ventilation required

Boswellia Serrata.Description: Boswellia Serrata is an herbal extract known for its anti-inflammatory properties. It has been explored as an adjunctive therapy to help reduce inflammatory cytokine activity in systemic conditions. While not a primary treatment for ARDS, it may offer supportive benefits in modulating inflammation.
Boswellia Serrata.Dosage: 300-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Boswellia Serrata.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Boswellia Serrata.Notes: Intended solely as a complementary therapy and should not replace standard ARDS management protocols. Its use should be approached with caution due to limited clinical evidence in this setting.
Boswellia Serrata.Alternatives: Curcumin or Omega-3 Fatty Acids, which may also provide anti-inflammatory benefits
Boswellia Serrata.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Lyme Disease.CategoryDescription: Lyme Disease is an infectious disease caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted primarily through the bite of infected Ixodes ticks. It typically presents with a characteristic rash (erythema migrans), fever, headache, and fatigue, and may progress to affect joints, the nervous system, and the heart if not treated promptly. Management involves early diagnosis and a course of antibiotics to prevent long-term complications.

Doxycycline.Description: Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that serves as the first-line treatment for early Lyme Disease. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis, thereby effectively eradicating Borrelia burgdorferi.
Doxycycline.Maximum: Dosage may be adjusted based on patient factors such as weight and severity of infection
Doxycycline.Notes: Typically prescribed for 10-21 days depending on the stage of the disease. Alternatives may be required for pregnant women and children under the age of 8.
Doxycycline.Alternatives: Amoxicillin or Cefuroxime Axetil may be used for those who cannot tolerate doxycycline
Doxycycline.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and dosing schedule

Japanese Knotweed.Description: Japanese Knotweed (Polygonum cuspidatum) is an herbal supplement known for its high resveratrol content and potential anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. It is sometimes used as an adjunct to support the immune system and overall health in patients undergoing treatment for Lyme Disease.
Japanese Knotweed.Dosage: 300-600 mg per day of standardized extract
Japanese Knotweed.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Japanese Knotweed.Notes: Intended solely as a complementary therapy and should not replace the primary antibiotic regimen. Consultation with a healthcare provider is advised to ensure safe integration with conventional treatment.
Japanese Knotweed.Alternatives: Cat's Claw or Andrographis may offer similar supportive benefits
Japanese Knotweed.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Scleroderma.CategoryDescription: Scleroderma, or systemic sclerosis, is a chronic autoimmune connective tissue disease characterized by progressive fibrosis, vascular abnormalities, and immune system dysregulation. It commonly manifests as hardening and tightening of the skin and may involve internal organs such as the lungs, heart, and gastrointestinal tract. Management focuses on symptomatic relief, slowing disease progression, and preventing complications through immunosuppressive therapies, supportive care, and lifestyle modifications.

Methotrexate.Description: Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used to reduce inflammation and slow the progression of skin thickening in scleroderma. It modulates the immune response and is often employed in patients with early diffuse cutaneous involvement.
Methotrexate.Dosage: Typically 7.5-25 mg once weekly, adjusted based on severity and patient tolerance
Methotrexate.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and monitored for toxicity
Methotrexate.Notes: Regular monitoring of liver function and blood counts is essential due to the risk of hepatotoxicity and myelosuppression. Folic acid supplementation is recommended to help mitigate side effects.
Methotrexate.Alternatives: Mycophenolate mofetil or Cyclophosphamide may be considered, particularly in patients with significant organ involvement
Methotrexate.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and dosing regimen

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric, particularly its active compound curcumin, exhibits potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. As a complementary therapy, it may help modulate the immune response and reduce fibrosis, supporting overall management of scleroderma.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments and lifestyle modifications; it is not a substitute for primary immunosuppressive therapy.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Alternatives: Boswellia Serrata or Omega-3 Fatty Acids may offer similar anti-inflammatory benefits
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Preeclampsia/Eclampsia.CategoryDescription: Preeclampsia is a pregnancy-related condition characterized by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks of gestation, while eclampsia involves the additional occurrence of seizures. Management focuses on preventing progression to eclampsia, controlling blood pressure, and stabilizing maternal and fetal conditions, with delivery being the definitive treatment once stabilization is achieved.

Magnesium Sulfate.Description: Magnesium Sulfate is the primary treatment used for seizure prophylaxis and control in patients with severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. It acts by stabilizing neuronal membranes and reducing neuromuscular excitability.
Magnesium Sulfate.Dosage: Typically, a loading dose of 4-6 g IV over 15-20 minutes followed by a maintenance infusion of 1-2 g per hour, or an IM regimen as per established protocols
Magnesium Sulfate.Frequency: Continuous infusion or repeated IM dosing as indicated
Magnesium Sulfate.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on maternal response and closely monitored for signs of magnesium toxicity
Magnesium Sulfate.Notes: Monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory rate, and urine output is essential to detect magnesium toxicity early. This treatment is administered in a hospital setting with constant supervision. Definitive management of the condition is achieved through timely delivery once maternal and fetal statuses are optimized.
Magnesium Sulfate.Alternatives: Other anticonvulsants, such as diazepam, may be considered in specific cases, although magnesium sulfate remains the gold standard.
Magnesium Sulfate.Preparation: IV or IM formulation prepared under sterile conditions
Magnesium Sulfate.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment protocol, patient weight, and duration of therapy

Garlic (Allium sativum).Description: Garlic is an herbal supplement known for its potential vasodilatory and blood pressure-lowering effects. It may offer complementary support in managing hypertension, although its role in preeclampsia/eclampsia is not well established.
Garlic (Allium sativum).Dosage: 600-1200 mg per day of standardized extract
Garlic (Allium sativum).Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Garlic (Allium sativum).Notes: Intended solely as a complementary therapy, garlic should not replace conventional treatments for preeclampsia/eclampsia. Its use during pregnancy should be approached with caution and only under medical supervision due to limited evidence on safety and efficacy.
Garlic (Allium sativum).Alternatives: Other herbal supplements with potential antihypertensive effects, such as Hawthorn extract, though evidence in pregnancy remains limited
Garlic (Allium sativum).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).CategoryDescription: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) is a common condition in older men characterized by the non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland. This enlargement can lead to urinary symptoms such as hesitancy, weak stream, nocturia, and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying. Management focuses on alleviating these symptoms, improving quality of life, and preventing complications through medications that either relax the prostate smooth muscle or reduce prostate size, along with lifestyle modifications.

Tamsulosin.Description: Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 receptor blocker that relaxes the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, thereby improving urine flow and reducing BPH symptoms.
Tamsulosin.Maximum: Dosage should be adjusted based on patient response; caution is advised when used with other antihypertensives
Tamsulosin.Notes: Patients may experience side effects such as dizziness or orthostatic hypotension. Regular monitoring of blood pressure is recommended.

Finasteride.Description: Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that reduces the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), leading to a decrease in prostate size and alleviation of urinary symptoms associated with BPH.
Finasteride.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and tolerability
Finasteride.Notes: It may take several months to see full benefits. Monitoring of PSA levels is advised, as finasteride can affect PSA readings.
Finasteride.Alternatives: Alpha blockers such as Tamsulosin or combination therapy for enhanced symptom control

Saw Palmetto.Description: Saw Palmetto is an herbal extract derived from the berries of the saw palmetto plant. It is used to support prostate health and alleviate urinary symptoms associated with BPH by modulating hormone levels and reducing inflammation.
Saw Palmetto.Dosage: Typically 320 mg per day of standardized extract
Saw Palmetto.Frequency: Once daily or divided into two doses
Saw Palmetto.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Saw Palmetto.Notes: Clinical evidence regarding its efficacy is mixed. It is intended as a complementary therapy and should not replace conventional treatments for moderate to severe symptoms.
Saw Palmetto.Alternatives: Beta-sitosterol or Pygeum africanum extract may offer similar benefits
Saw Palmetto.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Addison's Disease.CategoryDescription: Addison's Disease is a disorder characterized by insufficient production of glucocorticoids and often mineralocorticoids due to primary adrenal gland failure, most commonly from autoimmune destruction. It presents with symptoms such as chronic fatigue, weight loss, hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and electrolyte imbalances. Management involves lifelong hormone replacement therapy to mimic normal adrenal function, along with careful monitoring and adjustments during periods of stress or illness.

Hydrocortisone.Description: Hydrocortisone is a glucocorticoid used to replace deficient cortisol levels in patients with Addison's Disease. It is typically administered in divided doses to mimic the body's natural diurnal rhythm.
Hydrocortisone.Dosage: Typically 15-25 mg per day, divided into two or three doses (e.g., 10 mg in the morning, 5-10 mg at noon, and a smaller dose in the afternoon)
Hydrocortisone.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and clinical monitoring
Hydrocortisone.Notes: Dosage adjustments are often necessary during periods of stress or illness. Regular follow-up is essential to avoid over- or under-replacement, and patient education on stress dosing is important.
Hydrocortisone.Alternatives: Prednisone or other glucocorticoids may be considered, though hydrocortisone is preferred for its pharmacokinetic profile in mimicking natural cortisol levels
Hydrocortisone.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the prescribed dosing regimen and treatment duration
Hydrocortisone.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)

Fludrocortisone.Description: Fludrocortisone is a synthetic mineralocorticoid used to replace aldosterone in patients with Addison's Disease, aiding in the regulation of sodium and water balance and helping to maintain blood pressure.
Fludrocortisone.Dosage: Typically 0.05-0.2 mg once daily, adjusted based on blood pressure and electrolyte levels
Fludrocortisone.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on clinical response and monitoring of blood pressure and serum electrolytes
Fludrocortisone.Notes: Regular monitoring of blood pressure and electrolyte levels is essential to prevent complications associated with over-replacement, such as hypertension and hypokalemia.
Fludrocortisone.Alternatives: In some cases, adjustments in hydrocortisone dosing may provide minimal mineralocorticoid activity, but fludrocortisone remains the standard for mineralocorticoid replacement
Fludrocortisone.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment protocol and patient monitoring requirements
Fludrocortisone.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)

Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Description: Ashwagandha is an adaptogenic herb traditionally used to support adrenal function and help manage stress. It may assist in promoting overall energy and resilience in patients with adrenal insufficiency, though it should only be used as an adjunct to conventional hormone replacement therapy.
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Dosage: Typically 300-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy; it is not a substitute for conventional hormone replacement. Patients should consult with their healthcare provider before use, particularly in the context of hormone-sensitive conditions.
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Alternatives: Rhodiola Rosea may also provide adaptogenic benefits and support stress response
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Cushing's Syndrome.CategoryDescription: Cushing's Syndrome is a disorder characterized by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol, which may result from endogenous overproduction (such as adrenal or pituitary tumors) or exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. This condition manifests with features such as central obesity, moon facies, hypertension, hyperglycemia, muscle weakness, and osteoporosis. Management focuses on reducing cortisol levels and addressing the underlying cause, which may include surgery, medical therapy, or radiation.

Ketoconazole.Description: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent used off-label to inhibit adrenal steroid synthesis, thereby reducing cortisol production in patients with Cushing's Syndrome.
Ketoconazole.Dosage: Typically 200-400 mg twice daily, titrated based on cortisol levels
Ketoconazole.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and liver function monitoring
Ketoconazole.Notes: Regular monitoring of liver enzymes is essential due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. Alternative medications include metyrapone or mifepristone for patients who cannot tolerate ketoconazole.
Ketoconazole.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and patient response

Metyrapone.Description: Metyrapone is an adrenal steroid synthesis inhibitor that works by blocking 11-beta-hydroxylase, thereby reducing cortisol production. It is used in the management of hypercortisolism when surgery is not immediately feasible or as adjunctive therapy.
Metyrapone.Dosage: Typically 250-500 mg three to four times daily, adjusted according to cortisol levels
Metyrapone.Maximum: Dosage should be personalized based on biochemical monitoring and clinical response
Metyrapone.Notes: Frequent monitoring of cortisol levels is necessary to guide dosing adjustments. It may be used alone or in combination with other therapies to control cortisol levels.
Metyrapone.QuantityNeeded: Based on the prescribed treatment regimen and cortisol response

Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Description: Ashwagandha is an adaptogenic herb that may help modulate stress responses and potentially lower cortisol levels. While its efficacy in treating Cushing's Syndrome is not established, it may serve as a complementary therapy to support overall adrenal health and stress management.
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Dosage: Typically 300-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Notes: Intended as an adjunct to, not a replacement for, conventional treatments aimed at controlling cortisol levels. Consultation with a healthcare provider is advised before use.
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).Alternatives: Rhodiola Rosea may offer similar adaptogenic benefits
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Polymyositis/Dermatomyositis.CategoryDescription: Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis are idiopathic inflammatory myopathies characterized by muscle inflammation and progressive weakness. While polymyositis primarily affects skeletal muscles, dermatomyositis also involves a distinctive skin rash. Management aims to reduce inflammation, improve muscle strength, and prevent complications through immunosuppressive therapy, physical rehabilitation, and supportive care.

Prednisone.Description: Prednisone is a corticosteroid that serves as a first-line treatment by reducing muscle inflammation and modulating the immune response in patients with polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
Prednisone.Dosage: Typically 0.5-1 mg/kg per day, with the dose adjusted based on clinical response and severity
Prednisone.Frequency: Once daily, usually administered in the morning
Prednisone.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized and tapered gradually to minimize side effects
Prednisone.Notes: Long-term corticosteroid therapy requires monitoring for adverse effects such as osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, hypertension, and increased infection risk. Steroid-sparing agents may be introduced to reduce corticosteroid exposure.
Prednisone.Alternatives: Methotrexate, Azathioprine, or Mycophenolate mofetil may be used as adjuncts or alternatives to reduce steroid dependency
Prednisone.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and tapering protocol
Prednisone.AgeGroup: Adults (with appropriate adjustments for pediatric patients)

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric, particularly its active component curcumin, has potent anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties. As a complementary therapy, it may help reduce muscle inflammation and support overall management in polymyositis and dermatomyositis.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: Typically 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Intended as an adjunct to, not a replacement for, conventional therapies. Consistent use over several weeks may be necessary to observe potential benefits.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Alternatives: Omega-3 Fatty Acids or Boswellia Serrata may provide similar anti-inflammatory effects
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Scoliosis.CategoryDescription: Scoliosis is a condition characterized by an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, often accompanied by vertebral rotation. It most commonly develops during adolescence (idiopathic scoliosis) but can also occur in adults due to degenerative changes. Management depends on the severity and progression of the curve and may include observation, physical therapy, orthotic bracing, and, in severe cases, surgical intervention.
Symptoms: Abnormal lateral curvature of the spine

Orthotic Bracing.Description: Orthotic bracing involves the use of a custom-fitted brace designed to halt the progression of spinal curvature, particularly during growth spurts in adolescents with moderate scoliosis.
Orthotic Bracing.Frequency: Worn daily, typically 16-23 hours per day depending on curve severity
Orthotic Bracing.Notes: Proper fitting by an orthotist and regular monitoring by an orthopedic specialist are essential to ensure effective management and to adjust the brace as needed over time.
Orthotic Bracing.Alternatives: Physical therapy, observation for mild curves, or surgical intervention (e.g., spinal fusion) for severe cases
Orthotic Bracing.QuantityNeeded: One custom-fitted brace, with adjustments or replacements as required
Orthotic Bracing.AgeGroup: Adolescents and adults with progressive curves

Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).Description: Horsetail is an herbal supplement rich in silica, which may support bone health and strengthen connective tissue. It is used as a complementary approach to support overall musculoskeletal health in patients with scoliosis.
Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).Dosage: Typically 300-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support bone and connective tissue health; it is not a substitute for conventional treatments like bracing or surgery.
Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).Alternatives: Turmeric (Curcumin) or Omega-3 Fatty Acids may offer additional anti-inflammatory benefits
Horsetail (Equisetum arvense).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Tendinitis.CategoryDescription: Tendinitis is an inflammation or irritation of a tendon, typically caused by overuse, repetitive strain, or injury. It commonly presents with localized pain, swelling, and impaired movement in the affected area. Management involves reducing inflammation, alleviating pain, and promoting healing through a combination of rest, physical therapy, and pharmacologic treatments.

Ibuprofen.Description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce pain and inflammation associated with tendinitis. It works by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), which play a key role in the inflammatory process.
Ibuprofen.Maximum: Do not exceed 3200 mg per day
Ibuprofen.Notes: It is recommended to take ibuprofen with food to minimize gastrointestinal side effects. This medication should be used as part of a comprehensive treatment plan that includes rest, ice, and physical therapy.
Ibuprofen.Alternatives: Other NSAIDs such as naproxen or diclofenac
Ibuprofen.QuantityNeeded: Depends on treatment duration and dosing schedule
Ibuprofen.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)
Ibuprofen.Availability: OTC / Prescription depending on formulation and dosage

Turmeric (Curcumin).Description: Turmeric, particularly its active compound curcumin, has potent anti-inflammatory properties that may help reduce pain and inflammation in tendinitis when used as a complementary therapy.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Dosage: 500-1000 mg per day of standardized extract
Turmeric (Curcumin).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Turmeric (Curcumin).Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments. Consistent use over several weeks may be necessary to observe potential benefits. It should not replace standard therapies for managing tendinitis.
Turmeric (Curcumin).Alternatives: Boswellia Serrata or Ginger supplements may offer similar anti-inflammatory benefits
Turmeric (Curcumin).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use
Turmeric (Curcumin).AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)

Plantar Fasciitis.CategoryDescription: Plantar Fasciitis is a common musculoskeletal condition characterized by inflammation of the plantar fasciaâ€”the thick band of tissue running along the bottom of the foot. It typically presents with sharp heel pain, especially with the first steps in the morning or after prolonged periods of rest. Management often includes rest, stretching exercises, ice therapy, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to alleviate pain and reduce inflammation.
Symptoms: Sharp heel pain, especially in the morning or after rest

Naproxen.Description: Naproxen is an NSAID used to relieve pain and reduce inflammation associated with plantar fasciitis. It works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes, which play a key role in the inflammatory process.
Naproxen.Maximum: Do not exceed 1500 mg per day
Naproxen.Notes: It is advisable to take naproxen with food to minimize gastrointestinal side effects. This medication is most effective when combined with rest, ice, and stretching exercises.
Naproxen.Alternatives: Ibuprofen or other NSAIDs; in more persistent cases, corticosteroid injections may be considered
Naproxen.QuantityNeeded: Based on the prescribed treatment duration and dosing schedule
Naproxen.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)
Naproxen.Availability: OTC / Prescription depending on formulation and dosage

Devil's Claw.Description: Devil's Claw is an herbal extract known for its anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. It may help reduce pain and inflammation in plantar fasciitis when used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments.
Devil's Claw.Dosage: 300-600 mg per day of standardized extract
Devil's Claw.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Devil's Claw.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy, Devil's Claw should be used in conjunction with rest, stretching exercises, and other prescribed treatments, not as a replacement.
Devil's Claw.Alternatives: Turmeric (Curcumin) or Boswellia Serrata may offer similar anti-inflammatory benefits
Devil's Claw.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Cluster Headache.CategoryDescription: Cluster Headaches are a type of primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, severe unilateral headaches often centered around the eye, accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, or eyelid edema. Attacks occur in clusters over a period of weeks or months, followed by remission periods. Management focuses on rapid abortive treatment during attacks and prophylactic therapy to reduce the frequency and severity of episodes.
Symptoms: Severe unilateral headache (often around the eye)

Sumatriptan.Description: Sumatriptan is a selective serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonist used as an abortive treatment for acute cluster headache attacks. It works by constricting intracranial blood vessels and inhibiting pro-inflammatory neuropeptide release, thereby rapidly relieving headache symptoms.
Sumatriptan.Frequency: At the onset of an attack; may be repeated after 15 minutes if needed
Sumatriptan.Maximum: Do not exceed 12 mg in a 24-hour period
Sumatriptan.Notes: Effective for rapid relief of cluster headache symptoms. Patients should be monitored for cardiovascular contraindications and common side effects such as injection site pain and sensations of tightness.
Sumatriptan.Alternatives: High-flow oxygen therapy, Zolmitriptan, or other triptans
Sumatriptan.QuantityNeeded: Based on the frequency of attacks and treatment duration

Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Description: Feverfew is an herbal supplement traditionally used for headache prevention. It is believed to help modulate inflammatory pathways and reduce the frequency of headache attacks, potentially offering complementary support in managing cluster headaches.
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Dosage: 100-300 mg per day of standardized extract
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Frequency: Once daily or divided into multiple doses as per product guidelines
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy and not a substitute for conventional abortive treatments. Clinical evidence for its efficacy in cluster headaches is limited.
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).Alternatives: Butterbur Extract may offer similar benefits
Feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Vertigo/Benign Paroxysmal Positional Ver.CategoryDescription: BPPV is a common vestibular disorder characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. It occurs when otoliths (calcium carbonate crystals) become dislodged from the utricle and migrate into one of the semicircular canals, leading to abnormal stimulation of the vestibular system. Management focuses on repositioning maneuvers to relocate the otoliths and alleviate symptoms.
Symptoms: Brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movement

Epley Maneuver.Description: The Epley Maneuver is a series of specific head and body movements designed to reposition dislodged otoliths from the semicircular canals back to the utricle, thereby reducing or eliminating vertigo symptoms.
Epley Maneuver.Frequency: Typically performed once, with repetition if symptoms persist
Epley Maneuver.Notes: This maneuver should be performed by a trained healthcare provider or under proper guidance. Some patients may experience transient discomfort or nausea during the procedure.
Epley Maneuver.Alternatives: Semont Maneuver or Brandt-Daroff exercises may be considered if the Epley Maneuver is ineffective or not tolerated
Epley Maneuver.Preparation: No medication preparation is needed; proper positioning is essential
Epley Maneuver.QuantityNeeded: Procedure performed as needed based on symptom resolution
Epley Maneuver.AgeGroup: Adults (with modifications as needed for elderly or physically limited patients)

Ginkgo Biloba.Description: Ginkgo Biloba is an herbal supplement that may improve cerebral and vestibular blood flow, potentially reducing the severity and frequency of vertigo episodes when used as an adjunct to conventional treatments.
Ginkgo Biloba.Dosage: 120-240 mg per day of standardized extract
Ginkgo Biloba.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ginkgo Biloba.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy; it is not a substitute for repositioning maneuvers. Patients should consult with their healthcare provider before use, especially if taking other medications.
Ginkgo Biloba.Alternatives: Ginger supplements may offer similar supportive benefits
Ginkgo Biloba.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Meniereâ€™s Disease.CategoryDescription: Meniereâ€™s Disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. It is thought to result from abnormal fluid accumulation and pressure changes within the inner ear. Management strategies focus on reducing fluid retention and alleviating symptoms through dietary modifications, lifestyle changes, and pharmacologic treatments.
Symptoms: Sensation of fullness in the affected ear

Hydrochlorothiazide.Description: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to reduce fluid retention, which may help lower the endolymphatic pressure in the inner ear and alleviate symptoms of Meniereâ€™s Disease. It is often prescribed alongside a low-sodium diet to enhance its effectiveness.
Hydrochlorothiazide.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and renal function monitoring
Hydrochlorothiazide.Notes: Regular monitoring of electrolyte levels, especially potassium, is recommended as diuretics can lead to hypokalemia. Adjustments to the diet and medication may be necessary based on clinical response.
Hydrochlorothiazide.Alternatives: Betahistine (used in some regions), acetazolamide, or other diuretics may be considered
Hydrochlorothiazide.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the treatment duration and prescribing protocol

Ginkgo Biloba.Description: Ginkgo Biloba is an herbal supplement believed to improve blood circulation in the inner ear and may help reduce tinnitus and vertigo associated with Meniereâ€™s Disease. It is used as a complementary therapy alongside conventional treatments.
Ginkgo Biloba.Dosage: 120-240 mg per day of standardized extract
Ginkgo Biloba.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Ginkgo Biloba.Notes: Intended as a supportive therapy to enhance inner ear blood flow; it is not a substitute for conventional medical treatments. Patients should consult with their healthcare provider before starting any new supplement.
Ginkgo Biloba.Alternatives: Ginger Extract may offer similar benefits for reducing nausea and supporting vestibular function
Ginkgo Biloba.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Osteoarthritis.CategoryDescription: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and changes in the underlying bone, leading to pain, stiffness, and decreased mobility. It commonly affects weight-bearing joints such as the knees, hips, and hands. Management focuses on symptom relief, improving joint function, and slowing disease progression through lifestyle modifications, physical therapy, pharmacologic interventions, and, in some cases, surgical procedures.

Ibuprofen.Description: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to reduce pain and inflammation associated with osteoarthritis. It works by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, thereby decreasing the production of pro-inflammatory mediators.
Ibuprofen.Maximum: Do not exceed 3200 mg per day (prescription dosing) or follow OTC guidelines for lower maximum dosages
Ibuprofen.Notes: Should be taken with food to minimize gastrointestinal side effects. Long-term use may require monitoring for gastrointestinal, cardiovascular, and renal adverse effects.
Ibuprofen.QuantityNeeded: Based on the dosing schedule and duration of treatment
Ibuprofen.AgeGroup: Adults (with pediatric dosing adjustments as necessary)
Ibuprofen.Availability: OTC / Prescription depending on formulation and dosage

Boswellia Serrata.Description: Boswellia Serrata is an herbal extract derived from the resin of the Boswellia tree. It exhibits anti-inflammatory properties that may help reduce joint pain and improve mobility in individuals with osteoarthritis.
Boswellia Serrata.Dosage: Typically 300-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Boswellia Serrata.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Boswellia Serrata.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support joint health and reduce inflammation. It should be used in conjunction with conventional treatments and lifestyle modifications.
Boswellia Serrata.Alternatives: Turmeric (Curcumin) or Omega-3 Fatty Acids may offer similar anti-inflammatory benefits
Boswellia Serrata.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Urolithiasis (Kidney Stones).CategoryDescription: Urolithiasis, commonly known as kidney stones, is a condition characterized by the formation of crystalline deposits in the kidneys that can lead to severe pain, hematuria, and urinary obstruction. Management typically involves pain control, promoting stone passage through hydration and medical expulsive therapy, and, in some cases, interventional procedures when stones are large or obstructive.

Tamsulosin.Description: Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 receptor blocker used as a medical expulsive therapy to facilitate the passage of kidney stones. It works by relaxing the smooth muscle in the ureter, thereby easing stone transit, particularly for stones located in the distal ureter.
Tamsulosin.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and tolerability
Tamsulosin.Notes: Tamsulosin is used in conjunction with adequate hydration and pain management. Patients should be monitored for potential side effects such as dizziness or hypotension.
Tamsulosin.Alternatives: Other alpha blockers such as Alfuzosin or analgesic management with NSAIDs may be considered based on individual patient needs
Tamsulosin.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment duration and dosing schedule

Chanca Piedra.Description: Chanca Piedra, commonly known as 'stone breaker', is an herbal remedy traditionally used to support the breakdown and expulsion of kidney stones. It is believed to help relax urinary tract muscles and inhibit the aggregation of stone-forming crystals.
Chanca Piedra.Dosage: Typically 500 mg twice daily of standardized extract
Chanca Piedra.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Chanca Piedra.Notes: Intended as a complementary therapy to support conventional management, including hydration and pain control. Clinical evidence varies, so it should not replace standard treatments during acute stone episodes.
Chanca Piedra.Alternatives: Dietary modifications and hydrotherapy may also support stone prevention and passage
Chanca Piedra.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Cholelithiasis (Gallstones).CategoryDescription: Cholelithiasis, commonly known as gallstones, is a condition characterized by the formation of solid deposits within the gallbladder, primarily composed of cholesterol, bilirubin, and other bile components. These stones can be asymptomatic or may cause biliary colic, inflammation (cholecystitis), or other complications if they obstruct bile ducts. Management strategies range from conservative approaches, such as dietary modifications and pharmacologic dissolution, to surgical intervention in symptomatic or complicated cases.
Symptoms: Biliary colic (severe right upper quadrant or epigastric pain)

Ursodeoxycholic Acid.Description: Ursodeoxycholic Acid is a bile acid used to help dissolve small, cholesterol-based gallstones in patients who are not ideal candidates for surgery. It works by reducing cholesterol saturation in bile, gradually dissolving the stones over time.
Ursodeoxycholic Acid.Dosage: Typically 8-10 mg/kg per day, divided into two or three doses
Ursodeoxycholic Acid.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient weight and response
Ursodeoxycholic Acid.Notes: This treatment is usually long-term (several months to years) and is most effective for small, radiolucent stones. Regular monitoring with imaging studies is recommended to assess progress.
Ursodeoxycholic Acid.Alternatives: Surgical removal of the gallbladder (laparoscopic cholecystectomy) is the definitive treatment for symptomatic gallstones
Ursodeoxycholic Acid.QuantityNeeded: Based on treatment duration and dosing schedule

Milk Thistle.Description: Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) is an herbal supplement known for its hepatoprotective properties. It may support liver and gallbladder function and promote bile flow, potentially aiding in the management of gallstones as a complementary therapy.
Milk Thistle.Dosage: Typically 140-420 mg per day of standardized silymarin extract
Milk Thistle.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Milk Thistle.Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional therapies, milk thistle supports overall liver health but is not a substitute for medical or surgical management of symptomatic gallstones.
Milk Thistle.Alternatives: Artichoke extract may offer similar benefits in promoting bile production and liver function
Milk Thistle.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Gastrointestinal Bleeding.CategoryDescription: Gastrointestinal Bleeding refers to any bleeding that occurs within the gastrointestinal tract, from the esophagus to the rectum. It can be classified as either upper or lower GI bleeding and may result from a variety of causes such as peptic ulcers, varices, diverticulosis, inflammatory bowel disease, or malignancies. Management involves prompt stabilization of the patient, identification of the bleeding source through diagnostic procedures (e.g., endoscopy), and appropriate medical, endoscopic, or surgical interventions.

Omeprazole.Description: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that reduces gastric acid secretion, thereby promoting clot stability over bleeding ulcers and aiding in mucosal healing. It is commonly used in cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to peptic ulcer disease.
Omeprazole.Dosage: Typically, 80 mg IV as a loading dose followed by an 8 mg/hour continuous infusion; oral dosing may vary based on the clinical scenario
Omeprazole.Frequency: Continuous infusion for IV administration or as directed for oral use
Omeprazole.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on patient response and clinical guidelines
Omeprazole.Notes: IV omeprazole is generally initiated after endoscopic confirmation of a bleeding ulcer to maintain a high gastric pH and support clot formation. Patient monitoring for therapeutic effectiveness and potential side effects is essential.
Omeprazole.Alternatives: Other PPIs such as pantoprazole or esomeprazole; for variceal bleeding, agents like octreotide may be considered
Omeprazole.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment protocol and duration
Omeprazole.AgeGroup: Adults (with appropriate adjustments for pediatric patients as necessary)

Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Description: Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL) is an herbal supplement derived from licorice root with the glycyrrhizin removed to minimize side effects. It is used to support gastrointestinal mucosal healing and soothe irritation, particularly in chronic conditions like peptic ulcer disease. However, it is not intended as a primary treatment for acute gastrointestinal bleeding.
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Dosage: Typically 380 mg, taken 20 minutes before meals, up to three times daily
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Notes: DGL is intended as a complementary therapy to support mucosal healing and should not replace conventional treatments in the setting of active bleeding. Patients should consult their healthcare provider before use.
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).Alternatives: Slippery Elm or Marshmallow Root may offer similar gastrointestinal soothing effects
Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice (DGL).QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Skin Cancer (e.g., Melanoma, Basal Cell.CategoryDescription: Skin cancer encompasses a group of malignancies that arise from different cell types within the skin. It includes several subtypes, such as Melanoma, Basal Cell Carcinoma, and Squamous Cell Carcinoma. Melanoma is the most aggressive form, while basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are generally less likely to metastasize. Management depends on the type, stage, and location of the tumor and often involves surgical intervention, with additional therapies such as radiation, chemotherapy, or immunotherapy as indicated.

Surgical Excision.Description: Surgical excision is the primary treatment for most skin cancers. It involves the complete removal of the cancerous lesion along with a margin of healthy tissue to ensure total excision of malignant cells. In cases of melanoma, precise surgical margins and sentinel lymph node biopsy may be required to assess for metastasis.
Surgical Excision.Frequency: One-time procedure with follow-up evaluations as needed
Surgical Excision.Notes: Depending on the cancer type and stage, additional treatments such as Mohs micrographic surgery, radiation therapy, or adjuvant systemic therapies may be necessary. The choice of treatment is tailored to the patient's specific condition and tumor characteristics.
Surgical Excision.Alternatives: Mohs Micrographic Surgery or topical treatments (e.g., Imiquimod for superficial basal cell carcinoma) may be considered in select cases
Surgical Excision.Preparation: Performed in a surgical setting under appropriate anesthesia
Surgical Excision.Availability: Performed by a qualified surgeon; requires medical referral and prescription

Green Tea Extract.Description: Green Tea Extract is rich in polyphenols, particularly epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), which possesses antioxidant and potential anticarcinogenic properties. It is used as a complementary approach to support overall skin health and may help reduce oxidative stress associated with skin cell damage.
Green Tea Extract.Dosage: 250-500 mg per day of standardized extract
Green Tea Extract.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Green Tea Extract.Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments and lifestyle modifications. It is not a substitute for primary therapies in treating established skin cancer.
Green Tea Extract.Alternatives: Curcumin or Resveratrol may offer similar antioxidant benefits
Green Tea Extract.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and treatment duration

Diabetic Neuropathy.CategoryDescription: Diabetic Neuropathy is a common complication of diabetes characterized by nerve damage resulting from chronic hyperglycemia. It typically presents with symptoms such as pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the extremities, particularly the feet. Management focuses on optimal blood sugar control, alleviation of neuropathic pain, and prevention of further nerve damage through a combination of pharmacologic treatments, lifestyle modifications, and supportive therapies.
Symptoms: Pain in the extremities (especially the feet)

Duloxetine.Description: Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) approved for the management of diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain. It works by modulating pain signaling pathways in the central nervous system to reduce neuropathic pain.
Duloxetine.Dosage: Typically 30-60 mg once daily, with titration up to 60-120 mg once daily based on patient response
Duloxetine.Maximum: Maximum dosage generally does not exceed 120 mg per day
Duloxetine.Notes: Patients should be monitored for side effects such as nausea, dizziness, and dry mouth. Maintaining optimal glycemic control is crucial to complement pharmacologic treatment.
Duloxetine.Alternatives: Pregabalin or Gabapentin may also be used to manage neuropathic pain in diabetic neuropathy
Duloxetine.QuantityNeeded: Determined by treatment duration and dosing regimen

Alpha-Lipoic Acid.Description: Alpha-Lipoic Acid is a naturally occurring antioxidant that may help improve nerve conduction and reduce oxidative stress associated with diabetic neuropathy. It is used as a complementary therapy to support nerve health and alleviate neuropathic symptoms.
Alpha-Lipoic Acid.Dosage: Typically 600-1200 mg per day, taken in divided doses
Alpha-Lipoic Acid.Maximum: Dosage should adhere to product guidelines, typically not exceeding 1200 mg per day
Alpha-Lipoic Acid.Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments, Alpha-Lipoic Acid should be used under the guidance of a healthcare provider, especially in patients with complex medical conditions.
Alpha-Lipoic Acid.Alternatives: Acetyl-L-Carnitine may offer similar benefits for nerve health
Alpha-Lipoic Acid.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Peripheral Neuropathy.CategoryDescription: Peripheral Neuropathy is a condition characterized by damage to the peripheral nerves, resulting in symptoms such as pain, tingling, numbness, and weakness, typically in the hands and feet. It can arise from a variety of causes including diabetes, infections, autoimmune conditions, exposure to toxins, and vitamin deficiencies. Management focuses on relieving neuropathic pain, improving nerve function, and addressing the underlying cause through pharmacologic treatments, lifestyle modifications, and supportive therapies.
Symptoms: Weakness in the hands and feet

Gabapentin.Description: Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant medication widely used off-label to manage neuropathic pain associated with peripheral neuropathy. It works by modulating neurotransmitter release, which helps reduce abnormal nerve excitability and pain signals.
Gabapentin.Dosage: Typically starting at 300 mg per day, titrated gradually up to 900-1800 mg per day based on patient response
Gabapentin.Maximum: Dosage should be individualized based on efficacy and tolerability, with careful monitoring for side effects such as dizziness and sedation
Gabapentin.Notes: It may take several weeks for patients to experience the full therapeutic effect. Regular follow-up is recommended to adjust dosing as needed.
Gabapentin.Alternatives: Pregabalin or Amitriptyline may also be used for neuropathic pain management in peripheral neuropathy
Gabapentin.QuantityNeeded: Determined by the treatment regimen and titration schedule

Acetyl-L-Carnitine.Description: Acetyl-L-Carnitine is an amino acid derivative that supports nerve metabolism and has shown potential in improving nerve function and reducing neuropathic pain. It is used as a complementary therapy to support nerve health in peripheral neuropathy.
Acetyl-L-Carnitine.Dosage: Typically 500-1000 mg per day, divided into two doses
Acetyl-L-Carnitine.Maximum: Dosage should follow product guidelines or be determined in consultation with a healthcare provider
Acetyl-L-Carnitine.Notes: Intended as an adjunct to conventional treatments, it may help promote nerve regeneration and alleviate pain. Patients should consult with their healthcare provider before starting supplementation, especially if taking other medications.
Acetyl-L-Carnitine.Alternatives: Alpha-Lipoic Acid may offer similar benefits for nerve function and pain reduction
Acetyl-L-Carnitine.QuantityNeeded: Depends on product formulation and duration of use

Carotid Artery Disease.CategoryDescription: Carotid Artery Disease is characterized by the buildup of atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid arteries, which supply blood to the brain. This condition increases the risk of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and stroke. Management focuses on reducing risk factors, preventing plaque progression, and, in selected cases, restoring adequate blood flow through surgical intervention.
Symptoms: Sudden numbness or weakness in the face or limbs

Carotid Endarterectomy.Description: Carotid Endarterectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing atherosclerotic plaque from the carotid artery to restore normal blood flow and reduce the risk of stroke. It is typically recommended for patients with significant stenosis, especially if they are symptomatic.
Carotid Endarterectomy.Notes: This procedure is indicated for patients with high-grade stenosis (often >70%) or those who have experienced TIAs. Alternatives include carotid artery stenting. Postoperative management includes risk factor modification, antiplatelet therapy, and regular imaging to monitor for restenosis.
Carotid Endarterectomy.Alternatives: Carotid Artery Stenting, Medical Management with Antiplatelet Agents and Statins
Carotid Endarterectomy.Preparation: Performed in a surgical setting under general or local anesthesia
